description:
There are certain foods that I will put in my mouth and instantly smile because of how good it is. It's a facial expression that I've never seen myself, but those around me say that it's a type of delight that doesn't come often.

The dragon beard dessert is something you just have to try to really understand the taste and it is so worth trying because there is nothing quite like it.

The family who runs it are super sweet. They walked me through the history and process of the candy. There are boxes with 8 pieces of original, or mixed boxes that have 4 original and 4 of a different kind. Some of the other flavors include mango, strawberry, green tea and coffee.

I chose a mixed box of original and mango. The stringy cotton like fibers melt in your mouth and not that sweet like cotton candy is. The inside is this beautiful medley of nuts that become somewhat sticky and taffy like, but eventually just dissolve.

It really is a treat to have such a delicately made candy. 

It is a bit pricey for a box ($11) but for the handmade candy that is made with such finesse, love, delicacy and passion, it's so worth it.
author: Liz C.

description:
I've read and seen this dessert before on screen but never got to try it. We were walking to Union Square when we passed by this place coincidentally. It's so cool because a man was in a small clear booth actually making this confectionary. 

We went in a got the half original/green tea one. It's pricey. $11 for a small pack. These candy cotton like candies are dense and filled with peanuts. The actual white silky part doesn't have a particular taste but the peanutty filling is nice and nutty. It's not something I'll crave all the time, but it's definitely worth trying once in your lifetime.
author: Cynthia J.

description:
Had this while strolling through chinatown in San Francisco. 
So its stringy white cotton candy filled with peanuts that can also be flavored with mango. 
It's good but super sweet and you definitely need to gulp down a bottle of water because its dry and will stick to your soft pallet. Also a small container is about 11 bucks. I believe it has about 9 small pieces in it.
author: Joujou N.

description:
I want to give this place 5 stars but my SF Chinatown-born grandmother was just FLABBERGASTED that I would pay so much for Chinese candy. 

(Honestly, I was just so impressed by the owner and the ladies making the candy that I bought extra and also gave a tip.) Solid customer service which was definitely not expected in Chinatown and not at such a small hole-in-the-wall--I almost walked by the door! 

I got the matcha flavor but honestly could not taste the matcha? It's very messy to eat and tough to cut up/take bites out of because it's so fragile, but it's also melt-in-your-mouth. The inside is a potpourri of sesame, coconuts, and peanuts. It's an interesting texture that reminded me of silk worms, but it grew on me. Was it worth $11? Hard to say, because it is so labor-intensive to make. I do feel good about supporting the mom and pop business. 

I also was sold on ginger rock candy in a small bag for $4. Again, hard to measure value because I feel better about supporting these women than, say, a larger corporation like Trader Joe's where I usually eat my ginger candy. 

TLDR: pricey but unique, yummy (but with a texture that is not for everyone) flavor in a labor-intensive candy that are made in-house and not in many places around the country.
author: Lizzie S.

description:
FRAGILE WHITE HAIRY COTTON CANDY

Definitely not your typical Asian candy. These traditional Chinese candies are hard to come by in the US but of course SF's Chinatown would have a family owned business spinning and pulling apart white stuff into threads of sweet edible white 'hairs' resembling cotton candy texture. Warning: they can be messy to eat. 

FLAVORS:
Original
Strawberry
Mango
Espresso
Matcha

You can do half and half boxes. I bought 6 boxes (8 pieces per order) and spent nearly $58 bucks. That's pretty pricy for these tiny bite size sweet treats. 

The outer layer has an odd textured and if your not open to it then it can be "weird". It's best to eat them freshly made but they are good for 3 months if stored properly (said the owner). My favorite is the original because it's the original flavor that made me hunt for these candies for years. I liked the strawberry one too. Very light hints of strawberry. When you pop one in your mouth... you might cough because of the powder sugar being inhaled so quickly. And expect your mouth area to be covered in white - mine always does. If you bite into it, the candy will bust part. THEY ARE FRAGILE! In the middle are sweetened crushed roasted peanuts. Good stuff!

Until the next review...
author: Jane A.

description:
My friends and I were intrigued by the woman pulling noodles in the window. We went inside and met the owner, who gave us a short history lesson on what the woman was doing. 

This is a candy shop! The woman was pulling noodles that would be candied and wrapped around molasses. The owner said this is only one of three shops in the entire country that makes the dragon beard dessert! 

They do not offer samples since the process of making the candy is so labor intensive. We ended up purchasing a pack of candy with the original flavor and strawberry flavor. It's super messy to eat because the outside is so fine and instantly dissolves in your mouth. The inside is a mixture of different types of nuts and oils, and was super chewy. It was a different type of candy, for sure; and I'm happy I was able to try it. Not sure if it's something I would crave, but it was a great overall experience.
author: Liana B.

description:
Pretty tasty dessert but definitely not worth 10 dollars. The various flavors are EXTREMELY subtle (I bought almost all of them) and are not worth the money.  I would suggest just getting the original flavor and calling it good as the other flavors are really barely discernable.  I also do not suggest purchasing extra to take back home to fly anywhere as this stuff is extremely fragile and does not survive the flight. The owner told me that humidity will damage it but he didn't mention that even slight pressure decimates this stuff and let me tell you, oof...  destroyed on the flight.  So waste of money.  

So only buy what you can consume on the same day.
author: Joy G.

description:
A mom and pops store in Chinatown that makes their own dragon beard candy! Yes, this place is pretty pricy for a few pieces of candy but it is all handmade to perfection. You can tell the owner is very passionate about the candy and the history behind it. 

This was the best dragon papa candy i've had in my life. You get a total of 8 pieces in a box for 10 dollars or if you mix it with a different flavor, it is 11 dollar for a box. You can only mix one flavor into the box so it has to be half original and half another flavor.
I got the half original and half green tea flavor. The green tea tasted more like jasmine tea to me but it was still good nonetheless. 

They have someone at the window making the candy so you can see the process. It is not easy to make this candy and it amazes me how they make it so perfect.
author: Flora L.

description: Love the candy sold here but it is really expensive. If you are allergic to peanuts, don't come.  You can get different flavors but i stuck with the traditional. When you bite into it, the sugar on the outside pulls so it seems like you have a beard.   Over $10 for a box.
author: Mitzi W.

description:
Prepare to breathe in a ton of powder and become a dragon yourself because it's pretty messy to eat! I walked in Saturday afternoon, passing by seeing a lady folding and stretching silk-like threads of malt syrup in the front of the store. Walking in, it feels like a cute little shop tucked away in SF Chinatown. 

You get a box of 8 candies for $10, and $11 if you want flavors. I got a mix of mango and original for a pricey $11 as apparently mango and green tea are the most popular flavors. Mango is a tad bit sweeter than original, but both are equally good. There's toasted peanuts inside the intricately wrapped candies. Try to eat it when you've sat down or you'll definitely get powder everywhere!
author: Leona C.

description:
I spent the day in sf with my family today and noticed the shop when I walked by. You can see a person at the window working his magic. I've seen many videos about Dragon bear candy on social media so I had to give it a try. The shop is small and I was greeted by two very nice ladies who worked there. They offered a few flavors from mango, strawberry, coffee, green tea and original. I was surprised on how pricey it was ($11) for a small box, but I understand that it takes time, effort and skills to make this. I went ahead and purchased one with two flavors, original and green tea. 

I was really hoping to like this candy, but I didn't. Perhaps because I'm not use to the texture, but it was like eating a very dusty, chalky and dried up cotton ball. Not what I expected and definitely not a great taste in my mouth. Both of the flavors were tasteless. I couldn't taste any sweetness from the original and the green tea had an unpleasant bitter after taste. The only thing I enjoyed were the peanuts in the center. I am sad that this was not my cup of tea and that I just shoved $11 down the drain.
author: Sandra L.

description:
After dinner, I decided to mill around for non-ice cream desserts in the area and remembered that I'd been meaning to check this spot out a while back. I had a bunch of dragon beard candy when I lived in Beijing, but really hadn't happened upon it since coming back to the States.

Got there, and it's this small little mom and pop shop. In true Chinese fashion, no decorations save for the cardboard boxes of supplies stacked in the slim hallway that doubled as a walkway. 

There was a lady in the window making the candy, and the man at the counter who was introducing it-- an animated guy, really, who could easily double as a TV talkshow host given his charisma and friendliness. He told us about the different flavors, the history behind it, and teased that I would get a moustache from eating it.

Bought it (a little steep for the $9 price, but hey, it's one of those small splurge things) and ate it in a park. True to the guy's word, little strips of sugar EVERYWHERE when I bit into it-- it's like I got attacked by a huge fluffy cat and hair was left all over me. Original flavor wasn't too sweet, and the strawberry flavor was nice and light. The peanuts were very finely chopped and the handiwork on the whole thing was very professional.

Not quite 4, but its uniqueness makes it a spot you gotta try.
author: Nicole H.

description:
The Tam family's great ancestors used to make these furry desserts for the Chinese emperors. Now, it's available to all commoners like us. My sister and I purchased mango, original, coffee, and matcha. Each box contains 8 pieces.

Original: $10
Flavored: $11

Mango: sweet and nutty
Original: peanut-y
Coffee: bitter and nutty
Matcha: hint of matcha flavor + nutty

And the winner is...Matcha! It's not too sweet, so you'll end up eating several in one sitting.
author: Anna L.

description:
First time I've had dragon beard candy was in Canada and I thought, "Ehhhh..."

But now that I've found a spot in SF, Dragon Papa definitely beats Canada. According to the owner, there aren't many places that continue on the generation of making this kind of candy. Sadly, we came 30 minutes before closing time, so we didn't get to see him actually making it. This is family owned and from my understanding, the family has been making this candy for 5 generations now! The owner was great! I asked if he ever gets tired from making the candy, and jokingly, he says, "That's why I don't need to go to 24!" He kindly described the process and explained the different dragon beard candy flavors they had: Green tea, original, coffee, mango, and strawberry. I really appreciate the time he gave in explaining how each flavor will taste; especially if this is something new to your tastebuds. We ended up buying the half original and half green tea ($11). 

I remember the ones I've had in Canada being really sticky, hard to bite into, really powdery, and did not have much flavor to is. BUT Dragon Papa's (such a cute name btw!) was far from all of that! It was so easy to take a bite without making too much of a mess and the sweetness was perfect. You'll also get the perfect amount of crunch from the peanuts inside it. The flavor from this candy comes from the "dragon's beard" that's wrapped around the peanuts. Both original and green tea tasted exactly how it was described to us and was light and fluffy. BUT! The green tea flavor won my heart (and my stomach)! 

Warning: This candy could become your next addiction. 

Overall, this traditional Chinese candy is not only delightful but it is also fun to eat! You'll end up growing a dragon beard just after one bite.
author: Rachel C.

description: What are these things? They taste good but disappear immediately in your mouth faster than cotton candy. The texture is really hard to describe. There is a crunch, a bland cardboardish taste, then some interesting flavor and then poof it's gone. Evidence that you ate something powdery (if that's even a word) remains almost everywhere. Definitely a WTF moment followed by an urge to giggle. They are a playful confusing little treat, definitely worth giving a try at least once. My kids are hooked though - saying things like "what is this?" or "why are we eating these things ' with their mouths full causing explosions of powder to blast everywhere while laughing. Not sure what it really is, but Dragon breath is a pretty fun experience - at least for the first time.
author: John S.

description:
If you're looking for a taste of 'Chinese Cotton Candy', aka the Dragon Beard Candy, you've come to the right spot. If you're looking for a unique way of satisfying your sweet tooth, give this local dessert place a try!

According to them, they were first based in Daly City but then moved to the heart of Chinatown as most of the locals here loved having Dragon Beard Candy. For a lot of the locals it reminded them of having this treat back in China, and it quickly became popular first among the locals and later tourists. 

I ordered the half and half box of the Mango & Original dragon beard candy for $11. I think looking at photos online, I definitely thought it was going to be a lot bigger, but each candy is about the size of my thumb.

While I would say at $11 for 6 pieces of the dragon beard candy is kind of pricey, but knowing the process of how they make the candy justifies it somewhat, because it can take one person up to HOURS making the candy. Unlike most candy nowadays where you can manufactor it by machiene, they make the candy here using a similar technique to hand pulled noodles- only instead of noodles they use candy instead!

I got the half and half Mango & Original Flavor. If you're used to more traditional 'American' sweets, this isn't going to be as sweet, but it has more of a subtle sweetness.

The mango taste was more pronounced than the original flavor, but both were good in their own rights. They're slightly sweet on the outside with a peanutty coconut inside. 

Beware though, this candy is super messy to eat with, because the outside sugar coccoon basically crumbles into the center of the peanuttyness. But it's still really good!

I'd have to give Dragon Papa a 4. It's a cultural sweet that really can't be beat, and the only reason why I knocked off a star is because it's kinda pricey for the size of the candy. However, definitely a place I recommend if you're in the mood to get something unique and different to satisfy your sweet tooth!
author: Allison O.

description:
When I was little and living in Hong Kong, my parents would always take me to this grandpa's cart to get Dragon's beard candy. This candy makes me nostalgic. 

The Dragon's beard candy here is fresh. You can see someone making it in the window when you arrive. The shop is not very busy and they have the prices handwritten on a white board. 

This is like the upgraded bougie kinda place with flavors like honeydew, mango, and green tea. I went for the OG flavor which is just filled with peanuts. 

Upon first bite, the whole thing fell apart. Which is why I gave it the 4 stars. Normally they're a little more solid so when you bite into it, it still has it's shape and you aren't wasting any of the filling. 

Also 4 starts bc the PRICE was insane. These candies are supposed to be affordable and a cheap eat in HK. Instead this shop jacked up the price to $10/box and more $$$ for the ones with flavor. 

Had my thrill. It was okay. Will wait for my next HK trip for the real deal.
author: Junella T.

description:
Dragon beard candy. I was intrigued upon stumbling upon this place on Yelp and was glad I checked it out. It's conveniently located within Chinatown on Grant Ave (just keep walking straight upon passing Dragon's Gate) but is small and can be easy to miss. I bought a pack of their green tea + original flavors and, though pricey, it was worth trying at least once. 

The candy melted like a cloud within my mouth. Sweet and light - almost like cotton candy. I recommend eating a whole piece at once since it gets REALLY messy otherwise if you bite into it. Dragon beard candy isn't one of my all time favorite desserts but rather a novelty that I like to share with family and friends. Summary: dessert 4/5, ambiance 3/5, service 4/5.
author: Tina C.

description:
I've been wanting to try this spot for sometime and it's been sitting in my bookmarks for awhile. 

Finally got a chance to stop by and was greeted by a nice older man. He asked me what flavor I wanted and I went with the original.  A small box of 8 (?) runs $10 (no tax) and they look very odd to say the least. It reminded me aesthetically of a weird combo of a silk worm cocoon and the powdered shredded wheat cereal. 

Suffice to say I was nervous taking my first bite based on the unappetizing appearance but I put my faith in you Yelpers and you know what ...it wasn't that bad.  It was light, fluffy and sweet. 

Would it be something I stopped by for or craved??? Probably not , but I think it's definitely a spot that everyone should try at least once since it really is unique.
author: Rod M.

description:
*** In Short ***

Pricey cotton candy with an Asian twist.

*** In Depth ***

Okay, that summary is, admittedly, completely dismissing thousands of years of Chinese culture and history, and some very real technical differences, but let's be real: a lot of you will see this as being similar, or equivalent to, good ole Western cotton candy.

That said, Dragon's Beard does differ several regards: the types of sugars used, the amount of sugar content (cotton candy is about 5-8x sweeter), and the fact that it's often wrapped around things like crushed peanuts. A bit on the dryer, lighter, and more powdery side, this is great for those of you who like older Chinese style sweets, which are often not actually all that sweet!

For the rest of us, it makes for an interesting experience, but at $11 per box of eight, probably not one that you'll be hankering to repeat often.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - Crazy steep hills of Chinatown aside, Dragon Papa itself is a small shop with your typical high top glass displays, and narrow aisle walkway. As long as it's not too crowded (and it usually isn't), you shouldn't have too much trouble.

Bathroom - Pretty sure they don't have a public one.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Wow this dessert is exciting! There is a small window where you can see them make the dessert. The employee was so excited to tell us the story of this dessert. Only a few families in America are able to make this dessert, making me want it more. It is light and messy but then turns chewy. One of a kind dessert.

My top picks:
-dragon beard 
-excited employees

My Negatives:
-pricy. $10 for a container
author: Gina H.

description: The candy here was amazingly made. It wasn't too sweet and had a great taste in the actual candy. It was very messy but the shop owner was gery helpful in explaining everything there was about the candy! Worth a try!
author: Eric T.

description:
Dragon beard candy was something that my family would get when we were in Asia and we were very surprised to find a store selling fresh dragon beard candy in our very own SF Chinatown. From the outside, we can already see the candy freshly being made and the lady at the counter was very knowledgeable and told us that keeping the candy in the fridge keeps it fresh and crisp. 

Even though dragon beard candy is known for being expensive and their prices of over a dollar per candy is not that bad, but for us, it was still quite pricey. We ended up purchasing the original, green tea, strawberry, and mango flavors. The candy tasted like the ones we would find in Asia. They also sell mochi and hard mango and ginger candies.
author: Kristine P.

description: It's oddly good. But not the best that I've had. But I will say that this business really works hard to make the candy, inform people of it and all with a smile on their faces. It's expensive but it's all done by hand so you really can't complain. They have a variety of flavors, but I recommend always going with the classic. Give this place a visit if you're in town, it's worth the stop.
author: Guisela L.

description:
Gotta love when a small shop has a very narrow specialization and does it so well.  It may be $11 for a tiny box, but so are chocolates from bougie chocolatiers.  Probably not an everyday treat, but a nice indulgence.

Original: So delicate.  A web of candy strands encasing some crushed peanuts.  Reminds me a bit of pashmak, but much finer and less sticky.  Love how it starts out dry and turns chewy in your mouth.  Quite a bit richer than carnival style cotton candy due to all the fat content from coconut and sesame seeds.

Mango: Very much like the original, but with a very subtlse mango scent.  On one hand, I'm glad they didn't load this up with artificial flavors.  On the other hand, I was hoping for a bit stronger mango influence.
author: Adam B.

description: I didn't try the famed dragon candy because the husband isn't a fan of coconut so this review is for the mochi. The place is tiny - definitely a place to grab-and-go without a place to even stand and eat. The mochi was incredibly fresh (the dude was pounding it out in front of us) - plain flavored with sesame seeds sprinted on top. We ate the whole thing in one sitting! Would definitely recommend!
author: Michele L.

description: It's really hard for find Dragon Beard candy in the bay area.  So when we passed by this place we had to try it.  They make it fresh for you and for a box of 8 it was pretty expensive.  It cost 10.00 for a box of the regular flavor ones, but i guess you are paying for the memories of our childhood.  So i'll let you decide to see if this was worth it or not.
author: Belinda C.

description:
Food: I just came in and did a quick buy and go. I bought the traditional hand crafted candy where it is also known as the '10,000 strands' or something (I have watched a ton of YouTube videos about this and was eager to try some!) Unfortunately I was not able to try some right away after purchasing the goods but when I did try a piece the next day, it was not what I have imagined. The treat was pretty tasteless and dry and I was expecting something more.

Environment: The place was extremely small. There was no where to sit or hangout and it supported the more, pop in and pop out type of experience. The place was just barely furnished and had only the basics to be even called a business. 

Cost: Each of the treat I purchased was $10. Inside each container there are only 6 pieces of these desserts. This means each piece was basically $1.70 which is pretty steep for something that is made of sugar and nuts. 

Service: I gave 1 star here because the old lady who checked me out was so sweet and kind! I planned to deduct a star here too because when I used a credit card to purchase my goods, the lady automatically clicked on the 10% tip button without asking me- which I accepted because I felt bad but they should have told me or asked me if that was okay.

Uniqueness: Another star was given due to the uniqueness of this dessert. I had yet find this anywhere else which is why I came here in the first place. Now that I had my experience, I don't see myself stopping by here any time soon.
author: Jenny L.

description: Brought some dragon beard candy. The staff is so nice and friendly. This candy brings me back to my childhood. Told my kids about this good stuff. They both love them like I did when I was their age.
author: Betty L.

description: Haven't had dragon beard candy so can't compare hence it gets a 4. Not too sweet and the texture is like reading peanuts wrapped in silk
author: Zilla K.

description:
This place was a HUGE hit among our girls. The person making the candy in the window caught our attention as we made our way through Chinatown. After lunch, our little one begged us to come back and try it - and I am glad we did. 

When we entered the shop, we were greeted by possibly the best salesman I have ever encountered. He explained the labor intensive process to us, telling us only three families in the US make Dragon's Beard. He walked us through the flavors and his personal favorites and how sweet they were. He didn't need to pitch us on anything as we were already sold, but he could've convinced me to buy the store itself! He managed to do this all without being forceful. 

The candies themselves were delicious and exciting to eat. Members of our family old and young enjoyed it and it made for some very goofy pictures. Awesome place, will definitely be returning next time we are in San Fran.
author: Holland B.

description:
Right when we came in, the owner greeted us and explained to us their process. Not being familiar with Chinese dessert, we thought it was such a unique concept and loved that the original recipe could only be found in a few shops in the US. Loved how you could watch them make it in the window too! 

It is $11 for a box of 6, which is a little pricey, however we were willing to pay since it is such a small business. We got the original and the coffee. Both were so good, and especially when you let it melt in your mouth without biting! It can be a messy dessert - but so worth it. It starts off dry and nutty then melts into a gooey peanut sauce consistency - IT IS AMAZING.
author: Hannah M.

description:
Fellow helpers have made a fine decision in pointing me towards this business. This swirly, light, airy, slightly sweetened with but inside delighted my tastebuds. The man helping us was friendly, answered all our questions, and helped us choose our flavors. What a stellar experience when good service is met with an equally impressive product. This candy was unique and scrumptious. We opted for original and green tea. I loved the green tea. The swirly string like candy melts once it reaches your mouth.

It holds nicely in the fridge for a five days and can be frozen.  Although I preferred it fresh but we bought some to take back for my brother and SIL back in SoCal and had to refrigerate it in our RV. 

I'll make this another stop when I come back up to the City.
author: Tina S.

description:
Review #056 - 2018

After reading so many great reviews, I've finally managed to make my way over and try a few different flavors of their dragon's beard.

I sent the boys in to pick up the items while I waited in the car, parked at the red zone, because this is San Francisco Chinatown and parking is a nightmare.

The kids came back in the car, telling me how expensive the items were, which I honestly have to agree because $11 for 8 pieces of candy is quite steep.  But, I only live once and I might as well taste what the hype is all about.

I tried the original, which was actually pretty good and peanutty.  The kids said it felt like they were eating peanut butter because they stuffed a whole piece in their mouth and it stuck to the rough of their mouths.  Crazy kids!

I thought all the other flavors were just ok compared to the original.  It is a very interesting candy/dessert for those who've never had them before, but it's too dry for my personal liking so I most likely won't be coming back for them.
author: Sivilay T.

description:
The dragon has finally arrived for a special goodie treat right here in San Francisco's Chinatown! This smallest business named, "Dragon Papa Dessert" serves the customers of all ages to taste their finest selections of this well known traditional Chinese candy, the "dragon's beard candy!" The atmosphere is very active and on-going as I welcomed there. The concept is much normal and simple while entering the smallest interior lot. There, you'll see a window where a chef prepares to make the dragon's bear candy daily; dough after dough.

The employees here are doing an excellent job for making the customers like me a sensational service! No cons at all!

So, how does dragon's beard candy came from? This candy is made of these ingredients as follows: fine sugar, roasted peanuts, coconut, white sesame seeds, rice flour (it does have gluten) and additional additives. Once it got mixed altogether with the right recipes and preparations, it turned into a fluffy, cotton styled mini hard candy after 15 minutes of making.

Now onto the treat! I ordered the original flavor of the dragon's beard candy pack (costs $10 as of 2017). As I ate it, that candy tasted devouring and sensational! I can feel the exterior fluffs of the candy until I can feel the combo core of peanuts, coconut and white sesame seeds. Very fresh and elegant for that Chinese snack! Amazing!

Parking at Dragon Papa Dessert can be challenging to park. You can park at the nearby surface street parking nor the parking garage if it's available. Alternatively, you can also ride a bike, walk, carpool, ride sharing or public transportation easier without the hassles and gimmicks.

In the end, Dragon Papa Dessert is the most tremendous and incredible local mini dessert shop that I've ever discovered right here in San Francisco's Chinatown! A well, worthy visit! My rating: 4 solid stars.
author: William L.

description: The only place I know of to get these childhood memories ! So light and fluffy . We got the coffee combo with regular . I love these peanut chewy treats ! Brings back so much nostalgia . The only other time I got to eat these was in the Richmond night market in Canada ! If you like to try interesting sweets , come and try these Chinese unique treats .
author: Ang L.

description: Not good at all. No flavor, not sweet at all. So disappointed. I can understand now why there are only 3 families in the country that still know this art, which I can appreciate but the candy is just not worth eating. Kind of like biting into flour.
author: Nicole J.

description:
We discovered this place while walking around looking at stores.  All I needed to see in the storefront is "candy" and "dragon".  
The shop was empty but I'm sure it was because closing time was near.  There are different flavors, original, original & green tea, original & strawberry

::Dessert::
I didn't know what to expect and what to buy.   The owner was friendly and gave us a history of the dragon candy.  He also explained how it's made.  The candy is made of molasses and very delicate.   It is processed to a very thin string; looks like pieces of thread.  Take a bite and it's so soft it falls apart and you end up looking like you have a beard.  Inside is peanuts with something else.  I'm not sure what it is.  This is definitely a special candy that I've never seen before.  A great gift to take home to family & friends.

:: Customer Service::
Very friendly.

::M's Notes::
-Street parking or parking lots 
-No seating area
author: MarVy S.

description:
Boyfriend and I were in the area on a Saturday night around 7:30 PM. We called them to make sure they weren't sold out and they said that they continuously make more since they sell so quickly! 

We got Mochi and a box of Green Tea Dragon Beard Candy. While Derek (the shop owner) was warming up the Mochi, he was extremely friendly and told us how there are only three families in the US that still make Dragon Beard Candy - his in San Francisco, one in Irvine, and one in Boston. 

The Mochi is warmed up and then tossed in sesame seeds. You MUST eat this warm (as Derek insisted we do); eating it any other way would be doing it injustice. While the Mochi is warm, it feels as if it's melting into your mouth but you can still feel the chewy texture of traditional Mochi. I really enjoy how light and subtle the flavors are. One box of Mochi is $5. 

The Green Tea Dragon Beard Candy has a strong green tea taste and a more subtle peanut filling compared to the original. It also tastes less sweet, probably due to the natural bitterness of green tea. The original Dragon Beard Candy is deliciously delicate on the outside with a sweet and nutty filling of peanut, sesame, and coconut in the inside. Dragon Beard Candy dissolves in your mouth and becomes like that of a caramel texture as the sugar melts and sticks together, giving it a sticky and chewy texture. One box of Green Tea Dragon Beard Candy comes with four pieces of green tea and four pieces of original flavored candy for $11.

This is unfortunately a dying tradition in Chinese candy-making culture, so hurry up and go try it before it's gone forever (crying inside).
author: Sylvia L.

description:
My family and i was casually walking around chinatown until we stumbled across this store. When i saw at the window that the worker was pulling something, i knew in an instant that it was dragon beard candy! I quickly went inside the store and bought some right away.

Ive actually heard about this candy not too long ago cause it was trending on social media. I had to get my hands on it and i finally did!! MISSION ACCOMPLISHED! The way that they made their candy at the store was authentic and great tasting. This candy is very old school to chinese culture and it was an honor tasting it. I made sure i ate it with lots of love.

This store works really hard on their candy with all the pulling. Please tip them generously! They earned it
author: Lyl A.

description:
This is a rare Hong Kong style snack and that's why must try. The tiny shop isn't far walking from Portsmouth square. There's a man who handmade the dragon beard candy in front of the shop. He showing how he make the candy. 

I bought a box that has green tea and original flavor. There's no line at all. The staff told me if less sweet, should go for green tea or coffee. They also have strawberry and mango flavor. 

My hubby, my sister and I had fresh snack once I bought it. It's so soft and melted inside my mouth immediately. And I can taste a lot of nuts. The green tea flavor wasn't taste strong, I think it just taste like original flavor to me. 

The price may not be cheap, but it's worth to try. One box has 8 candies with different flavor cost $11. But if only want one candy, it will cost $2 each which is not worthy.
author: Jaane F.

description:
Fun! I hear there's an Instagram craze over these hand-pulled candies, so my friend and I decided we'd stop by after getting boba at Steap. There was a line but they moved through it very quickly. The owner(?) was VERY charismatic and friendly, which I REALLY appreciated since I've gotten flak in Chinatown for being Asian and not speaking Mandarin (hey, I'm only half... and 4th generation at that). He explained how the candy is made and what it's supposed to taste like - hard and icy at first, and then soft and chewy. Very cool!

We got a pack of 8 (half mango and half original) - never had anything like it! The closest way I could describe it would be like cotton candy with a crunchy exterior, with a chewy nut caramel nougat interior. Be careful, though - when you bite into one, expect a puff of sugar in your face! Totally caught me by surprise.

I'd recommend the original flavor - but I'd say the other flavors are be worth a try, if you reeeaaaaaallly like mango, or honeydew (or whatever other flavors they are offering at the time). I had the mango, which was alright, if not a little odd - the mango flavor was very slight, which was actually a plus for me since I didn't care for the mango + peanut combination. The original though? Yum! 

Ultimately, it's not my kind of candy, but it is fun and definitely worth a try!
author: Larissa M.

description:
At first my boyfriend was convinced this place was only a tourist trap, but we were both pleasantly surprised with how good it was. He told us they started at koi palace in Daly City and finally opened up a shop of their own! (Right on mom & pop shops :D )

We got the half original and half matcha flavor for around 11$. The matcha was SO good, you taste it right when you bite into it and it's very light. But it worked really well because it just melted in your mouth. They have other flavors like coffee, strawberry and mango as well. The price is pretty steep, which is the only reason why I'm knocking down a star, but they are handmade. I just wish we got a little more for the prices! 

But honestly speaking, it was my first time trying it and I loved it here! My boyfriends had it before elsewhere, but he said the quality here was really good compared to what he's had. I recommend this place if you've never tried it, but because of the pricing and amount I probably won't be here too often!

QUICK Tip: if you pay cash it's a flat amount, with debit/credit you have to pay tax!
author: Melanie T.

description: Very friendly and a nice place . They have different flavors of the candy and they taste good. We got green tea and original, it is a bit messy when eating but worth it!
author: Crystal G.

description:
If you love peanuts and candy, you'll love this! It's a whole-in-the-wall gem! 

It's peanuts wrapped in stringy wrapped candy. I brought the strawberry and regular flavor -- I loved both equally!

It's a bit powdery as well, and it will dry out your mouth almost instantly!  It's worth the sugar, but I'd say 1-2 pieces is just perfect, and save the rest for later.)

It's considered to be traditional Chinese candy and the owner who still runs the store is so cute! If you're curious, she'll give you some background on the store and talk about the many famous people that have stopped by! 

Try a few and enjoy watching them make it in front of the window!
author: Giovanna R.

description: So i went here because im used to the turkish/syrian version which i believe is called floss halva. I expected this to taste the same or similar, and it does, but it is not as sweet, and i dont like that the filling is crushed peanuts, i wish they sold some without any filling. Not the worst, but wouldnt go again. Wish they would sell individuals rather than a box, to taste at first.
author: Dania F.

description: Looks exactly like the ones I got off a street vender in Hong Kong but does not taste the same.  The candy is way too dry and not able to taste the candy at all and cost $5.50 for a small box of 8 !!The pulling technique was awesome, but the candy base was not good at all.
author: Peter W.

description: What a fun, novel treat! It was neat to see how they were made and eating them made us laugh. We tried original and mango, and the original was our favorite. The proprietor was very friendly and informative.
author: Jenna W.

description:
It looks yummy when you saw they were making it in the front, but it is a trap! I repeat, a trap to your eyes, your tummy, and your wallet.

Once you stepped into the store and was introduced to a 8 small pieces of so-called dragon beard candy with a hefty price of $11, you (and your monies) feel invaded. But your stupid eyes told you it looks so nice, it must deserves the price! Then you proceeded to pay $11 in cash since you are shitty cheap ass and you don't want to participate in the tax system. 

Then you go out, put the first bite in your mouth. Hesitating destroying your $11. It is minimum wage somewhere in the US. Feel bad yet?

Now you are here, trying to digest the idea that you just throw $11 out of the window. Why? Because you couldn't digest the plain taste of the candy. 

-----

Why the 3 stars? The staffs are so nice.
author: Stephanie V.

description:
Dragon beard candy is a delicacy that was once reserved for the Chinese emperors. The candy derives from the stringy, hair-like consistency that resembles a less sweet version of Cotton candy. Its a process made entirely by hand as well!

It's essentially fermented honey mixed with flour and stretched into 16,000 thin strings and put together with nuts as a filling. It was absolutely delicious and a great dessert for those who don't want anything too sweet.

This store is in Chinatown, and is from a family that moved here from Hong Kong (Tsim Sha Tsui). This is a business that specializes in this candy and has been alive for five generations!

You get a mini beard after eating the candy and it's so satisfying! The flavors include the original, coffee, mango, strawberry, and green tea.

Right now it's about $10 a box because it's takes a long time to make the candies!
author: Sheena T.

description:
3.75 from me, but I'll round up to a 4.
I'm usually skeptical of places in Chinatown. The quality of most places is subpar, and ok at best. Regardless, I went to try this place out since I haven't had dragon's beard candy since I was a kid. In addition, this type of candy is incredibly hard to find in America.

It's a fairly small shop but you can watch the employees make the candy from outside. They have the traditional candy, and also flavoured dragon's beard candy, which include coffee, green tea, mango, and strawberry. Each box has about 8 candies, and if you get the flavoured ones, the box contains 4 traditional candies, and 4 flavoured candies. It's $10 for the traditional dragon's beard candy, and $11 if you decide to get a flavoured one.

The candy itself is fairly decent. As expected, it's incredibly sticky in your teeth, but it tastes good, and I always love the taste of peanuts. I just wish that there were more peanuts inside. It seemed as though sometimes I was only chewing on the sticky outside, inside of munching on peanuts.
author: Desmond C.

description:
After seeing a video about this candy, we really wanted to try it! We heard about this place, and the idea of seeing the candy being made on spot got us going.
The place is very small, but the owner is nice and has great customer service skills. 
We got 2 boxes of the original ones, but there are different flavors and mixed match boxes. 
The candy is good! Very fun to eat, we loved to discover something new.
We'll definitely get a box everytime we visit SF!
author: Melissa G.

description: Delicious and unique Chinese candy. Watching the process of making them is worth the price alone but these slightly powdery and chewy treats are very tasty and all natural! Love them! I love the original flavor best.
author: Tony D.

description:
This is a small whole in the wall, if you walk too fast and don't pay attention you can miss it. However, at the window there's a lady that is pulling/demonstrating how they create the candy (Dragon Beard Candy). The price for the Original is $9 or10 & for Half Original & other flavors like Matcha (Green Tea), Strawberry, Mango or Coffee are $11 per box and each box had 8 of the little candies. 

I grew up having this and I loved it but hadn't had any in a long time. I some how found it in Yelp and when i was in the area, i had to try it. I say everyone needs to try this at least once. 

The outside is like string like candy/cotton candy. But once it is in your mouth and you chew on it, it gets chewier and the inside is peanut, sesame & coconut.
author: Christina H.

description:
I mean yeah the dessert is super unique,
Though that doesn't make it a must-try.

Some may like this overpriced treat,
But I found it too dry.

(at least it's good for Instagram stories )
author: Jason X.

description: Nice and friendly staff; however, the Dragon Beard Candy made here is not as good as what I had growing up in Montreal, Quebec. Also, at $11/box, I think it is outrageous. As another Yelper put it, it is like eating cotton candy with peanut filling inside. The outside has no flavor at all. I was disappointed at best. Note that my review is purely based on how the candy tastes and not authenticity.
author: Thuc V.

description: Yes! Small shop and such unique candy! Handmade with different flavors. I got the original and mango. Both very good, though they kinda tasted the same.
author: Melissa C.

description:
Reminds me of my childhood. Delicious!!!

Peanutty flakey sweet deserts. It's hard to describe this desert to someone who hasn't had them before but hey areeee delish. Although they are a bit sweeter than I remember eating in Taiwan I actually don't think I've ever had this here in the states.

They have many different flavors but the original is always the best!

Prices are very reasonable and it's a great snack to share!
author: Tammy K.

description:
Interestingly I was thinking about Dragon's Beard candies the day before and the next morning I saw a video from Eater showing how to make it at home.  It must be a sign!

Got to Chinatown and bought a box of original flavor ($10) for 8 pieces.  It has to be the original flavor and nothing else.  Basically it's hand pulled sugar (think hand pulled noodles) into thousand and thousand of fine strands like dragon's beard then wrap with chopped peanuts, sesame, and coconut shreds inside.  Such artisanal candy is hard to come by nowadays.  Melt in your mouth but do be careful and don't choke on it.  Took one bite and it tasted exactly the same as I remembered.  So awesome!

After watching the video, I would be more than willing to pay the $10 than trying to DIY.  Ants aren't my favorite pets!
author: Shirley H.

description:
What a labor intensive process to make this dessert!

Super messy, eat over the side walk.  Also, not recommend for children...unless you want to watch one explode in a sugar high! haha.
author: S F.

description: It really lives up to its hype. So delicious and different than what I expected! I got two different flavors and both had similar yet distinct tastes. You get to see the person actually make it in front of you too! The shop is also very small and cute.
author: Samantha L.

description: 4 pieces original. 4 pieces green tea. The original one has more peanuts. Just to try once But not worth $11!!! Our Vietnamese ko kéo is much better tasting. So powdery the hubby kept coughing when he ate it.
author: K P.

description:
Dragon Papa Dessert 

Dragon Beard Candy (龍鬚糖) 

This is a handmade traditional sweet originated from China. It is made fresh in front of you. Delicate, light & airy when you take a bite. 

Believed to originate in the Han Dynasty & reserved for the ruling class. Dragon Beard is named after the thin white strands resembling a Chinese Dragon's beard. 

Ambience -
Space is limited, so don't expect to eat there. Good to buy as souvenir to bring back, but make sure to buy it on your last day & keep in fridge (low humidity).     

Wait time -
Almost no wait, they make it in front of you. 

Taste - 
We purchased mainly original & green tea flavor. They try to put a modern twist on a traditional desert by offering different flavor selections. Taste unique & a good experience.
author: C C.

description: It's not cheap, but it's probably one of the best Dragon Beard Candle you can get outside of China. My mom grew up eating this and she loved it.  Highly Recommend!  We get some whenever we are near Chinatown.
author: Eddie H.

description:
Dragon Papa! Even the name is adorable! This family-run sweets shop is so enchanting. How could you not be lured in by the sight of someone making handcrafted sweets from the window booth? It feels like you're transported to one of those outdoor food markets in Asia where each booth has a unique concoction.

I had been wanting to try Dragon Papa's dragon beard candy for a while, but while I had braces, I wasn't allowed to have anything sticky or brittle. I wasn't sure what the texture of the candy would be, so I waited until I got my braces off, but much to my delight, the candy is as fluffy and cloudlike as it looks (aka, I wouldn't even have had to wait until my orthodontic work was done before indulging)! Unlike American cotton candy though, it's not sickly sweet. It's a nice, mild sweet that allows you to focus on the texture. 

As others have rightfully said, the owners and employees here are friendly and sweet and are proud of their craft. Although the prices are much higher than what you'd expect from a store in Chinatown, it's such a rare treat to experience these kinds of goodies and they do take a lot of effort to make. This is NOT some hyped up, mediocre gimmick like the "dragon's breath" frozen cereal thing at Japantown. This is Chinese traditional gourmet dessert at its finest.
author: Brittany L.

description:
Dragon Papa, what a neat find in San Francisco. I had first encountered this candy on a trip to Singapore, but I find this treat here to be much more tasteful! A pulled sugar that is eventually made to look like a dragon's bread, it is then carefully spun into a nice pill like shape that can be enjoyed. 

DESSERT: We opted for the original flavor that was not very sweet and had a nice peanut flavor on the inside. This treat should not be eaten in one bite, but two bites should be sufficient! The peanut flavor and the sugar makes for a great combination! 

A fun place to go for $10 a box. You can also get fruit flavored ones as well. It is a fun kind of dessert place that is more unique in touristy SF Chinatown!
author: Albert H.

description: Truly unique and artisanal, this candy is hand pulled and hand stuffed with a peanut and sesame filling.  It's not overtly sweet but sweet enough that you can enjoy with some hot tea.  Absolutely delicious.  I always pick up a pack while in SF.
author: L D.

description: This place is over rated.  Their candy is not worth it all.  Tried the coffee flavor one and it was not good.  The candy fell apart as I picked it up. I had this candy more than once in different places and none fell apart while I picked it up. Can't believe it cost $11 for a box of 6.
author: Ariel E.

description: A random find but glad I came across it! I think my first time trying Dragon candy was in Singapore but I was so drunk that I'm not sure if it was the same thing or not. One thing they did have in common though is that white stringy consistency. It was slightly sweet but I really love it for its interesting texture. The green tea flavor was good too-- just less sweet. Try out this novelty candy!
author: Kimberly B.

description:
Great place and warm welcoming. The owner was really nice and welcomed me introducing the dragon beard candy and the story behind it.
It was a fun experience :)
author: Monika B.

description: Didn't even know this place existed! Haven't been to Chinatown in ages. It a tiny little shop that draws you in with the loads in front demonstrating / making the dragon beard candy. Enough to draw you into the shop and look at the different flavors. They have posters on the wall that talks  about the history of the candy. Smart marketing! We got a box of the mango and plain flavored dragon beard candy. We also got a small box of the mochi candy. It was definitely fresh but mango was an ok flavor, prefer the plain one. Lots of peanuts and a whole lotta mess while eating it!  Kids had fun while eating it. One of the few places that sells these.
author: Alicia A.

description:
This is the coolest little place tucked into a small space in San Francisco's Chinatown! The owner is super nice and moved his family business here from Hong Kong over a decade ago. They make "dragon beard" candy, which is a delicate, sweet dessert made of peanut paste wrapped in spun molasses sugar. It is fun and messy to eat. In the tradition of Chinese sweets/desserts, it is not actually overly sweet. 

You can also watch them make the candy in the window and it's interesting to see the sugar threads being handled.

This is probably one of VERY FEW places in the US that has this candy available, so definitely try it!
author: Angela T.

description: I had originally seen something like this on ig and was really interested in how this was made a complete piece of art. The flavor is complementary and not too overwhelming I extremely enjoyed it. Its nutty, smooth and chewy.
author: Esmeralda C.

description:
I remember first trying these on a recent trip to S. Korea and loved them! 

Saw this place while walking around Chinatown. Very small family owned shop. They make the Dragon Beard Candy right at the window. 

$10 for original and $11 for mixed flavors. I tried original and mango and loved both of them. Even my mom loved them! Will be back for more!
author: Daniel S.

description:
Second time here. Small little place. The little old lady was very nice and kind. The other woman next to her was also friendly.

Yes, $10 for 8 of these dragon bread candy. $11 for mixed two flavors. We picked original and mango. It was delicious! I don't remember our first visit having so much flavor. 

We originally came to purchase one for my mother because she really likes these. But we decided to open it and try a little ourselves. Turns out we killed the whole thing so we had to turn around and purchase another package. LOL

It was fresh, tasty... sweet and had lots of flavor! My son loved how it got all over the place too. Clothes, hair, mouth. It was a fun little treat. Highly recommend everyone to try at least once!
author: Yee W.

description: Amazing!! This place makes tasty flavors in unique fluffy dessert!! Definitely have to check with out!!! Love this place and the price is reasonable!
author: Lana S.

description: We stopped in because they were making candy in the window.  We were hesitant to buy the candy but we gave it a try.  It was fantastic.  It was so fresh.  If you like peanuts give it a try you won't regret it!
author: Jennifer P.

description: Delicious dessert! My first time having these since I was a child and they definitely did not disappoint! The prices are a bit steep but definitely worth it for so much labor. You can also watch them hand pull it! Such a fun place!
author: Helen z.

description:
I saw a video many years ago and I couldn't stop watching. It was of a young Korean street vendor who spoke decent English and was making Dragon Beard's candy for some German tourists. His delivery and personality was so delightful to watch that I kept watching it over and over over the year even to present day. However I never had it until just last week. 

So the wife and I decided to skip cooking one night to hit Hong Kong Hot Pot. On the way though I saw this tiny ass store with someone stretching the honey disc. I said "Let's eat fast before this shop closes!"  Which we did :)  they have several different types but since the shop was closing up, we just got the regular kind with peanuts, sesame, and another kind of nut powder. There might've been honey on the inside too. $10 for a small box. 

As you can imagine, the excitement to eat this was so overwhelming. We walked to the BART station and the whole time I'm walking too fast for the wife, who asked me to slow the hell down. Ha! I said (in my mind) I'm gonna eat one of these at the station so you better keep up! Cash only. 

So when we got to the station I opened the packaging and felt the light fine strings of stretched powdered honey strands. I took one bite and I was HOOKED. The combination was way too delicious! The dried honey strands just dissolved in your mouth and at the same time, you flight the flavors of the mixed nut powders.  

lol and behold a week later after decimating half the box watching Netflix, Tessa B asked me if I took pics. I could've sworn my wife ate the rest but a las, she did not! So I took some pics of the packaging and the TWO remaining treats. While she probably forgot about them, I didn't remind her either and savored every little bite :)

Time to make another excuse to hit Chinatown!
author: Bob K.

description: Always liked the dessert since I was little. Really glad to found it again in the US. If you never had it before, try it. You will like it and found it interesting.
author: Sarah N.

description: Little bit pricey. $11 for 8 little pieces. The candy was ok. But the sticky rice was really yummy. They are surrounded with peanuts and sesame. I would recommend the sticky rice over their candy.
author: Putin J.

description: I have never had such a unique style of candy. The master chef takes what looks like a hard tub of wax or gel and basically turns into a thinly strands of candy. When you taste it, it becomes hard to start, but once it starts melting in your mouth and being able to chew it. It was delicious. You will love the peanut flavor when it explodes in your mouth.
author: Alan L.

description:
This place is bomb! 

It's a small shop in Chinatown and they only sell the dragon beard candy. Last time when we went, they had original, coffee, and strawberry. When we walked in the store, the employee was so friendly asking us we had any peanut allergies, and I really appreciated this little gesture.

The dragon beard candy is very soft and crumbly on the outside. I suggest eating the piece in one bite otherwise I imagine yourself to be a powdery white mess. The inside of the original tastes similar to crunchy peanut butter (best way I can describe it).

It was $9 for 8 pieces. Yes, it's pricey, but this snack is so unique that it's well worth it.
author: Kristen L.

description:
This place is located in the heart of Chinatown but a must see!   The owners are the NICEST people ever and an older couple who makes you feel welcome.  I just wanted to hug them and adopt them as my own grandparents.  

So these treats are extremely unique.  Imagine a chick o stick wrapped in this weaved hardened cotton candy.  That's what these remind me off.  The center is light and peanuty and coconutty (yes, those are made up words) and melt in your mouth.  

I bought the 6 pack of the original mixed with coffee which is the owner's favorite.  They traveled well on my flight back to Colorado and I stuck them in the refrigerator right when I got home to keep their texture.  Delicious and a must try!
author: Tammie W.

description: Very interesting desserts & great service. Excellent job explanation on each dessert. All desserts contain peanuts, sesame seeds, & coconut.  Very yummy and a must stop after dinner in Chinatown!
author: Diane C.

description: I was looking through my box of items from my San Fran and found a business card. Similar to what you get at the Night Market in Richmond, BC, however, this is a store dedicated to Dragon Beard. It is $$$ 'cause you're actually paying for a cultural novelty whereas in Vancouver it is very very common, especially in Richmond BC. We were in Chinatown walking around and I had off mentioned a week before to the bestie about Dragon Beard, therefore, instead of waiting until home we decided to split a small piece. I recently uploaded a pic of myself on my Facebook page of it since I am organizing my San Fran scrapbook at the moment and forgot about this gem. I bought a few pieces of Green Tea flavor to bring back to the hostel to share with the front desk reception as a way of saying thank you for helping us with the room that day. I had a long conversation with the lovely girl about Vancouver and how large of an Asian population we have and the desserts, therefore, bringing this back for her and the staff was a welcome. On the same note she recommended some other places as well. The owners were are super nice. It was very busy with both locals and tourists as it was a small shop.
author: Shila B.

description:
THE BEST DRAGON WHISKERS I'VE EVER HAD!

These are handmade delicacies that date back to ancient China. I've always had these as a child in SoCal, but the ones from Dragon Papa taste SO much better!

This place is located in Chinatown, and you can even see someone making these in the display window as well. Each box was $9 for the traditional flavor. These deserts usually are on the pricier end because they take so much time and technique to make. 

It's sugar stretched out and spun to make it look like "whiskers." They are wrapped around crushed peanuts. When I took a bite in these, the peanuts and the sugar was so fresh and crunchy. 

I came from SoCal, so when I visited Dragon Papa Dessert, I bought all of the boxes that they had made (that was a total of 5 boxes). My boyfriend thought I was crazy, but these things are too good to pass up.

I brought these back home to SoCal and my entire family thought these were these best dragon whiskers that they have ever had also. My only regret is not stopping by again before my flight to buy (maybe 5) more boxes.
author: Michelle S.

description:
Unlike most of the reviewers for this place, I can't actually speak to the dragon beard candy from this store...but I can attest to the mochi that they also sell. 

When I dropped in to buy some mochi, I was impressed by the owner's charisma and politeness, greeting everyone and telling them abut the products he has to offer. The mochi that they sell is (I think) somewhat premade and then when you order, they heat it up and then coat it in peanut/sesame mix and sweeten to your liking. It is definitely really hard to make mochi fresh so this is one of the few places where you can at least get warm mochi. 

The service was great and there's definitely a true dedication to food that shows through! Prices may not be the cheapest ($5 for a small box of mochi), but then again, this is San Francisco...
author: Isabella C.

description: Great traditional Chinese candies. Just one star off for the high price. Get the green tea and original combo-the green tea is surprisingly intense in flavor! Note that these candies have crushed peanuts inside. Also: go sit and eat these at the nearby park (exit the store and turn right, then right again and you'll see the park down the road). You'll be treated to a bunch of Chinese folks playing instruments/singing/dancing. Tip: public restroom is available at the park too (no restroom in the store).
author: Ang C.

description:
We walked by this store and I immediately gravitated to it because I had eaten a ton of this stuff every time I went back to Taiwan. Without asking the price, we bought a box of it. Holy smokes, is this expensive. Yes, I know, this isn't Asia and I wasn't expecting Asian prices, but the mark-up is absurd. This is literally 10x the cost of what I would pay in Taiwan.

Flavor wise - it was a bit drier and less flavored than I remember having. It's okay. Would I buy it again? Probably not from here. 

I mean, I'm totally down to support local businesses. They also show you how they make it from the window, which is a nice eye-catcher. If you're a tourist, maybe try it for fun, but I wouldn't go out of my way to buy this.
author: Nadia S.

description: This dessert is hard to describe. The outside looks like hair. Once, you put it in your mouth, the outer layer melts away. Inside the "hair" is a mix of nuts and I think honey. They come in boxes of 8 pieces of candy for $10 if you're just getting original flavor or $11 if you're getting half original, half special flavor. I got half original, half green tea. The green tea flavor was spot on! $11 is a bit pricy but this is a delicacy. I can truly say I haven't had a dessert like it before. If you're looking for something unique, this is it!
author: Lexi R.

description: My boyfriend and I stopped by while in Chinatown and the man helping us so was so nice! And the candy was delicious :)
author: Karla R.

description:
Dragon Papa Dessert specializes in a old-fashioned Chinese candy called Dragon's Beard.  It's made with a special sugar and is either spun or hand-pulled and then is wrapped around a mixture of peanuts, sesame seeds, and coconut.  Some people might compare it to cotton candy, but personally, I can't do that.  It doesn't really have that melting factor that cotton candy has when you put it in your mouth.  In fact, the texture is quite unique.  At room temperature, the sugar is chewy when you eat it.  But, when it's refrigerated, it's crumbly.  Which is my favorite?  Wow.  Tough question.  I liked both.  Also, it is definitely not as sweet as cotton candy, which for me, is a good thing.

While the candy itself is delicate and delicious, the best part of this shop is the "show" that they put on.  The shop itself is small.  But, there is a window in the front in where passersby can watch Dragon Papa himself hand-pull the sugar.  It's a fascinating process.  Think of it like hand-pulling noodles, but even harder.  Sugar is definitely harder to pull (like taffy).  But, watching this man, pull these delicate shreds of sugar, is amazing.   So amazing that it is very common to see the sidewalk blocked because of all the people watching and taking pictures (this guy included).
author: Jamie J.

description:
July 9, 2016 Saturday - 2:45 PM for snack
2 Adults and kid
 
Atmosphere - 4 stars
Food - 4 stars
Service - 4 stars 

Background - Walking around China town and stumbled across this place.

Atmosphere - Small store with a few people working it.

Food
  Snack - Maybe I am losing my sweet tooth with old age.  The way candy was spun is interesting and unique.  So I am glad I took part in the experience but the candy was not a wow for me.  Perhaps I thought it was going to be more like cotton candy, not even close.

Service - It was alright.  The lady was like a grandma working behind the counter so you are a little more patience with her. 

Future - Sure, it is touristy thing.
author: Paul S.

description: We came here because we saw the reviews on Yelp and it was well worth the trip. The candy is delicious and made right in front of you. The owner was really nice and knowledgable. He told us the history of the candy and how there is only three families making it in the world. So fun!!!
author: Karla S.

description: This is one of the coolest things I have seen...or ate! If you are in Chinatown, make sure to stop by and eat the desserts of the emperors! It looks like cotton candy but tastes like a caramel peanut deliciousness! Make sure to take a pack back home, the fam will love it!
author: Joe H.

description: My fav dessert in Chinatown. It's right on grant st very touristy. There is a lady that makes the roll with crunch peanuts inside right on the window it's very hypnotic
author: Cecilia G.

description:
Great demonstration, great candies! 

You'll get drawn in as you watch one of the personnel hand-pull the candy into the "dragon beard" strings. Once inside, as for a free sample of Chinese Traditional Mochi. Unlike its ice cream filled cousin, this one is warm and melts in your mouth with its sweet and nutty exterior. 

Definitely by one of both! That's what we did and we don't regret it!
author: Farrah S.

description:
Omg this is sooooo good!
It's really hard to find outside China, and it's handmade right in front of your eyes.
Not overly sweet with a crunchy, cool nutty taste and it gets chewy once it's in your mouth. I literally finished the whole box in under half an hour, and now I'm craving more!!
author: Becca D.

description:
A gem that I wish there were more places that makes this candy! 

It's sweet but not overly sweet. Balanced with nuts and prob barely there salt. Some say it's like cotton candy because it just melts in your mouth, but it's more of a saying than a comparison of taste. I personally am not a fan of cotton candy because it is too too sweet and it's no different than scooping a tablespoon of sugar into your mouth. 

Only tried original and green tea flavors. They also have coffee, mango, and strawberry. Original flavors are $1 cheaper and I also enjoy original flavor better than green tea. They do combos of flavors so I bought half green tea and half original (comes in box of 8, 4 flavors of each for total of $11).
author: Chau N.

description:
I stumbled upon this place during my afternoon walk and was mesmerized when watching the man in the window make these delicate desserts.

I bought the original ($9) and was interested in the mochi ($5).  Let's just say that none of these items stood a chance.  The mochi was given to me fresh and warm.  Next thing you know, I nearly ate the entire box.  I gave 3 pieces away so I wouldn't turn into a pig.  

The original dragon beard was so good and that didn't stand a chance either.  I think my boyfriend and I consumed the whole box in about 5 minutes.

This looks like a tedious process to create, but it's nice to enjoy these special treats that aren't very common.  Please stop by and support this small business.  It's so worth it.
author: Rachel L.

description:
This is a tiny store that hand pulls the hard disk of maple! The man behind the counter said it takes 3 hours to make 6 boxes (or the other way around, I forgot). They have traditional, mango, coffee and strawberry flavors. We got the traditional (regular peanut) and strawberry. WOW!!!! It was messy to eat but the flavors of the strawberry was not to sweet and well worth the $11/box. The work that goes into each candy.
The man (sorry didn't catch his name) said there is only 2 places in the US that makes the dragon beard candy which is his shop of course and one in San Diego (yesssss out of all places! My home) but a Korean makes it (I'm on the hunt for him here) so he's not sure of the quality. It's nothing I've ever had before and a great "1st time".
author: Tee C.

description: Went here during lunch after having some soup. This place is small but clean. Tried the green tea and original dragon beard candies. I enjoyed the original more than the green tea, it kinda tasted like ummm...soap?  but I will go back and inhale the original anytime!
author: Stacey H.

description:
I stumbled across this place when I was in Chinatown in San Francisco during my trip. I wanted to try a different unique treat, something I wouldn't find in Southern California. We came in and I was so happy I tried this spot! 
The man there, I believe the owner, is the absolute sweetest man! He is very informative and friendly. He was teling us about the candy and how it's made. He was very nice. I think it made the experience even better! 
We tried the mochi and the dragon beard candy. The mochi... Oh man... I still dream about it. It's so yummy! He makes it fresh and sweetens it as you wish. Oooohhhhh MYYYYYYYYYYY! It was amazing. The peanuts were perfect. I loved the candy. The beard candy was yummy as well. Peanut buttery tasting. You can't go wrong. But oh man, that mochi.... Try it! You won't regret this place!
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Wow first time seeing this place and I been through Chinatown, San Francisco a lot. What caught our attention was the guy was standing near the window area pulling noodle to make the "cotton candy ". It was so cool seeing the technique to make this right in front of your eyes. When you go inside you will see another person wrapping the candy with the white thin thread looking that is edible. The store is very small and it's a very traditional item. 

The taste of it is unique and delicious candy. It is a bit chewy and it is filled with peanut and sesame. The flavor and taste is amazingly mouth watering.
author: Cindy W.

description: Derek and his family have a great story and are doing much more than merely selling candy. The reason why the candy is so expensive is because of how labor intensive the process is/depending on the weather (because humidity affects the candy) -- 1 hour can only produce 2-7 boxes of the candy so it really is a true novelty. How do I know this? Because Derek is so friendly and knowledgable about the Dragon Beard candy.
author: Em M.

description:
First time trying the dragon candy in person! I have seen all of the candy on youtube, and heard about them in other asia countries. I finally get to try it! 
Price is okay for the amount of candy you get in one box. 

I got the original candy and it cost $10!! The other flavors are; strawberry, chocolate, and coffee. I myself got the original. 

Service was attentive. The owner/employee at the counter was really nice and helpful. He did say that the chocolate is the sweetest. There are 2 other employees that are helping out as well. The thing about this store is that in the front, you can see the employee making the candy itself. Once you go in the store, you see another employee making the candy. I am glad that I got a fresh new bath of candy once I came in. 
The candy itself tastes pretty good. It can get pretty messy while eating it with a toothpick. It has sweetened peanuts inside and the texture is cool as well. 

I would recommend buying this as a souvenir in SF, because they only make it in SF and not in any other states.
author: Susan L.

description: Employee gave an awesome history of the candy and made sure that we did not have any nut allergy. Very descriptive of the main ingredients and consistency. Small spot, but you can't miss the employee making the candy right in front of the shop. Ordered the original and coffee; not too sweet just right. Nutty in the middle, hair-like texture that melts in your mouth.
author: Vanessa G.

description: Dragon Beard Candy is wonderfully light dessert and melts in your mouth really fast. Delicious.
author: Mo M.

description: 1.5"X1" and only 8 pieces for $10.80 (with taxes), I paid with a credit card and the old lady swiped my card and added 15% tip on it without asking me, when question, she said if I don't agree to it, I can take it off...WTF, it's not like the desserts is a total ripoff and what is the tip actually for?...taking two steps to the fridge and adding a printed label on it? Needless to say, not worth my $10..and won't come here again.
author: Dee J.

description: This place is an absolute treasure and the family working there is delightful. The gentleman who helped us was the fifth generation of his family to create these historic candies. He was warm, informative, cheerful and clearly passionate about his art. This was a major highlight of our trip to San Francisco.
author: Tara Y.

description:
So I'm a mighty sucker for dessert, when searching for a dessert place on Yelp in San Francisco (something I can't find in New York), it was quite the challenge. 

Somehow I stumbled upon this nice little boutique where the service was very upfront and personal. I asked a lot of questions about what this is exactly and the gentleman was very patient which is something I appreciated.

These little desserts were definitely very unique. I bought two different versions, the original and strawberry. They primarily take cash but they do take card too just that then they have to charge you taxes. I liked it since it was quite the unique texture but it got stuck to my teeth a little bit too often and although I understand the delicacy of this dessert but I'm not sure if its worth $2.50 a piece. 

Would I come here again? Sure! Only for people that loves unique desserts!
author: Yuena L.

description:
More people need to know about this place and it's authentic candy. The candy is also found in Vietnam (where I'm from and originally had it) and it's SO GOOD. 

The candy literally melts in your mouth and is an excellent combination of the flakiness of the "pulled" sugar outside and nut/coconut inside. We tried the strawberry variation and that was really good too.
author: Tommy D.

description:
So cool to watch it made and fun to eat!  We got the coffee and strawberry flavors, plus some of the ginger candy bagged on the counter. 

We loved it and had fun eating it! It may not be for everyone, but we liked it. The ginger candy tastes like a  a super crisp ginger snap cookie, yum! Stop by and enjoy the show and try the candy with an open mind.
author: Karen R.

description:
This place is fantastic. If you have never tried this stringy, powdery candy, definitely do it! One box of candy has 8 pieces with a price of $10 or $11 per box depending on whether you choose 1 or 2 flavors. The original flavor is filled with a peanut powder. My favorite is the green tea flavor as it has a slight citrus flavor to it, adding to the freshness of the candy.

The candy can be stored in the refrigerator for up to 3 months. In addition to the candy, definitely get the mochi as well. It is also mixed with the peanut powder creating a mild sweetness. You can adjust the sweetness by adding sugar if you like. This is a rare treat and hard to find in other cities. If you are ever in the city, I suggest splurging a bit to try this delicious Asian treat.
author: Sandy L.

description: Yummy, peanutty morsels. The dragon candy appears dry, but the minute it hits your mouth it turns to a chewy confection. Don't skip this unique dessert.
author: Neysa T.

description: It was our first time trying this deliciousness and well we had to come back and purchase additional boxes because we ate our "souvenir gifts".  The owner is super nice and explained his family's history with this delectable treat.
author: Dina H.

description: So fresh.  Expensive,  yes, but so are macaroons,  according to my teenage daughter.    To me,  it was definitely worth the indulgent splurge to bring back a childhood memory from over 44 years ago in Hong Kong.  So glad to have found something here in the states and let my kids experience it.  Had it once in Canada at a night street market,  but this was def more memorable, tasty and fresh.  Customer service was super (surprisingly)  friendly,  chatty and welcoming.  They even let us try a sample of the ginger candy before buying.  (Get that,  too.  It's quite good, and interesting! ) 5 stars. Happy momma.
author: Keriena T.

description:
Dragon beard candy is a dying art but thank goodness for Dragon Papa for keeping such a nostalgic confection alive!  Each time I bite into one of these pillowy chewy goodness, it reminds me of my childhood w/ my gma.  This is usually the one "souvenir" request I would ask her to bring back from Asian and even in recent years, she have said it's harder and harder to find since people (even in Asia) no longer know how to appreciate it.

Well...heck, my sweet tooth still does and I'm lucky that Dragon Papa made a fixture for themselves in Chinatown.  Their location is great too, right on Grant St. so not only can locals enjoy them, they can introduce it to the thousands of tourist that visit our city each year.  These sweets are great for souvenirs as well since it's not something you can find in every Chinatown. 

I'm not usually a peanut fan but this is one confection that I can appreciate the peanut and coconut combination with the stringy sugary texture.  You can taste the freshness in each bite and if you would like to savor them for a few weeks, they keep well in the fridge.  

I have yet to try their fresh mochi but it reminds me of the ones my gma make.  Oh, they also have ginger rock candy that looks pretty neat.  Definitely something I plan to buy for the adults in my family the next time I stop by again.
