This is definitely one great mom and pops shop that I enjoy supporting.  The mom behind the counter totally reminds me of my gma, just a nice friendly lady that strikes up a conversation with everyone that walks into her shop.  Regardless if you buy anything or not, she welcomes you with a smile.

If you are in the area, stop by and catch one of their candy pulling demonstration right by the window....it's pretty neat, even if you are not into sweets!
author: Janetto L.

description: Happened to walk by as she was making these in the little shop and my curiosity drew me in.  It's a little like cotton candy with a peanut/coconut inside.   The owner explained the process of how they make them. What a great little treat.
author: Sean L.

description: Great bite size desert soft on the outside very airy like cotton candy but nutty in the inside. Yummy must try
author: Aldo G.

description: People kept telling me about this place, but we never go. But finally we actually went here on my 3rd trip go sf. It's interesting on how it's made and looks...but I'm not too impress with it. It does have flavor and good texture. But it's not my cup of tea
author: Tan D.

description: Where do you get some fresh dragon beard candy? From past visits to San Fran, Toronto, or Beijing, I would only be glad to find a small local vendor, or someone selling pre-packed dragon beard candy. My sister loves dragon beard candy so if a place I'm visiting has it, bet I'm going to bring some back for her. NYC does not have good ones, at all. This place is an absolute must if you're stumbling across Chinatown. It a cute little store that sells handmade dragon beard candy. You can watch everything in action from the store front.The prices are quite expensive and the staff there are rude and I felt unwelcomed there as I wanted to watch them make it before making an order.
author: Carrie C.

description: Not what I expected. It wasn't all that great. The best part was watching the lady make the candy in the window. The candy was a little pricey.
author: Lida A.

description: What a fun authentic candy! It starts a bit dry but transitions to chewy and just sweet enough! A must try for anyone that enjoys a nutty sweet!
author: Karleigh M.

description:
Dragon beard candy in SF, rejoice! I used to enjoy this lovely and fun sweet treat of rolled molasses, peanuts, sesame and coconut as a child. Several years ago while traveling in Xian, I stumbled upon an unassuming street vendor making these divine treats and went bananas (think Ratatouille moment when the food critic gets transported to being a child upon a taste of the delicious soup). It was a rare find even in China!

I first found out about this shop located on Grant through Kiva of all things. The store owner was seeking crowdfunding help for his business and I immediately bookmarked this place, excited to try it. 

When I finally made my way over with a friend, I had a great experience. Right away your eyes are greeted by a window display where a girl's pulling and making fine strands of molasses, or white "dragon beard." I loved how this craft is incorporated and highlighted, way cool to just watch! After stepping into the tiny shop, the owner welcomed us and asked if we've had the candy before, before warmly giving us an overview on what this candy is and how it's made and also running through the flavor varieties they carry. There is the traditional (more peanuty taste), green tea, strawberry and mango. A little something for every palate. I opted for a tray of traditional and one traditional/ green tea mix. $10 a tray is definitely a steeper price than how much they cost in China! But I had to get 'em. The taste is on-point. I love the traditional flavor and found the green tea flavor to be a bit medicinal (gotta stick to the original). It is aromatic and fragrant and the dragon beard isn't overly sweet but light and fun to eat. 

I recommend anyone curious to pop in and try out the dragon beard candy. It's a bit educational, cultural peek into this fast-fading candy making craft. But be careful, you might end up with a white beard yourself when you devour these babies!
author: Jing D.

description:
Cash Only 

Imagine if cotton candy and taffy had a child and that's what Dragon Papa texture is like 

At $2.50 a piece ($10 for 4 pieces) it is a little steep but when you see the level of intricacies it takes for one to be made it makes sense

I recommend sticking with the original flavor (mango you can barely taste and strawberry is too artificial). Have yet to try the coffee so TBD on that

Overall Thoughts

A unique dessert worth trying at least once
author: Eddie W.

description:
While I admire the historical and cultural backstory behind these, I will admit they are definitely something that is a one-time-try for me. 

The texture on the first bite is VERY unique.. a little soft from the white strings of sugar, and then quite hard as your teeth continues to get through the layers of all the sugar strings and peanuts. In a few seconds, the candy will be verrrrrry chewy! Think chewy peanut butter bar. While this whole procedure is happening, strings of sugar will be everywhere and stick onto your lips, so definitely save these to be eaten at home! The candy itself is perfectly sweetened though - not too much, not too little.

I'm glad I was able to give these a try! This does make for an adventurous tasting or a nice souvenir if you're not in SF's Chinatown very often, but most likely I won't be coming back.
author: Kris C.

description:
Great candy, little expensive but gladly to support this authentic business..
The candy still tasted great even a week
later, will get more when visit China town next time
author: Chi Y.

description: The staff is really friendly and kind. Great candy. They also take credit and debit here so that's good
author: Jasmine F.

description: This was such a neat experience. The dessert is what i would describe as string-like cotton candy but less sweet with a granola like peanut flavored underlay. It was incredibly unique and definitely something you need to try at least once! The staff there were also very entertaining
author: Eliza L.

description:
I'm not a candy man. I can't make a sunrise, sprinkle it with dew, and cover it with chocolate and a miracle or two. Nope, that's not my thing, but my curiosity was piqued by the presence of this Chinatown shop although it's more accurate to call it a walk-in closet with a true candy man out front. He methodically makes something called Dragon's beard candy which I have never heard of before I started reading the reviews for this place (photo: http://bit.ly/1IbqUqR). It goes back two thousand years to the Han Dynasty when the imperial court chef needed to amuse the Emperor with something sweet.

Apparently he was the Donald Trump of the Far East. He probably wanted to build a wall, too, to keep the Keebler elves out. The intricate process here involves turning rice flour into small threads which are sweetened by sugar, coconut, sesame seeds and peanuts. It looked and felt like the kind of packing material you get when you order those Mexican beer bottle masks from eBay. Luckily, it tasted better than that, at least I'm presuming it did since I don't usually eat the packing material. With a highly unusual texture, it was more like a grainier version of cotton candy with a chopped peanut filling (photo: http://bit.ly/1JT0TnF).

I liked it since it wasn't cloyingly sweet like other Chinese sweets, but it does cost an exorbitant $9 for a box of eight (photo: http://bit.ly/1JsUk4U). With a relatively quick shelf life, the value is questionable unless you have friends with low blood sugar. At least I impressed the waitress at Chef Hung who saw the box in my possession and simply said "Expensive". That's right, sister. They sell a few less expensive items like ginger candy and even mochi (although I didn't see it) but why. If you're coming to see the candy making show, then you must be here for the Dragon's beard. Pull it if you dare. They should sell half-orders if you ask me. Truly a novelty.

CANDY - 4 stars...definitely unique and you certainly pay the price of that
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...walk-in closet
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...the young man at the counter certainly sells his product with zeal, the candy maker is very quiet
TOTAL - 4 stars...pull that Dragon's beard if you dare
author: Ed U.

description: Due to the reviews, I was expecting something very tasty because I've never had dragon beard candy before. We went in and it was a very quaint store with an eccentric owner. He was super sweet and explained everything to us. We got the half strawberry and half original one. It's filled with peanuts, which we didn't know. The candy didn't impress me and was nothing special. When we walked out, a man told us that this wasn't the best place. He said it was over priced and there were a lot of better stores. This was sad to hear!!
author: Monica B.

description:
Amazingly excited to see we got our freshmade dragon beard candy....after all these years since the HK airport I have patiently waited......finally this long lost candy is back......

We headed over to SF just for this today.....we got 6 boxes and ate them immediately.....one piece each that is....9 bucks for 8 pieces....so worth it

Happy happy we are.....
author: Leslie Y.

description:
CASH ONLY.  Walked to Chinatown after Turtle Tower and it's pretty far, but I had lots of time on this lazy Sun 8/30/15.

Nobody except me when i went.  One guy working in the window you can watch him making the candy.  Another guy inside taking your money.

Guy inside was hammering the ginger candy to small chunks, I asked for a sample and he gave me a tiny piece.  It was ok, not enough ginger for me.

I bought a $9/container of the dragon beard candy.  I asked for a fresh one and he got it from the window guy that had some stacked up.  Young guy said they make them fresh every day.

Young guy said you can refrigerate them to make them harder, keeps for a few months.  If you want them soft, eat them right away or within 3 days.

Dragon Beard Candy $9
Mochi is $5
Ginger Candy $3 (smaller bag) or $4 (bigger bag)
Bottle water $1
Soda $1.5

CASH ONLY!!
author: Ann L.

description:
I stumbled upon this place the other day while in the neighborhood and I am glad I did. The candies were very interesting and delicious. It's one of those great whole-in-the-wall gems in the city. The guy working there was also very friendly and informative.

Only downside is that it's too expensive for what you are getting.
author: Gokhan T.

description:
Mmmmm, this is a melt in your mouth delicacy I wasn't aware of until my friend told me about it. We came here to try a nostalgic candy for older Chinese generations. 

It was hard to find this place because it's such a small shop. Just look for a chef sitting in front of the window making some white fluffy goodness. 

The normal flavored candy costs $9 for 8 pieces  whereas the flavored ones are $10. The other flavors included mango, strawberry, and coffee. We decided on getting two of the regular flavors. They take credit card.

We stood outside with the toothpicks they gave us and took a bit too much of a bite. Since we have never tried this before, we were surprised to find that there was so much molasses and peanuts inside. So we would stand there chewing like cows while people walked by haha. The outside is nice and soft and originally my other friend thought it was made out of bird's nest. It is actually just flour and starchy goodness. 

Although pricey, it is worth getting once in a while and I suggest you eat them as soon as possible and refrain from storing them in the cold because the filling can get a little hard.  I think drinking milk tea alongside this would make for a good combo.
author: Jessica Q.

description: Okay, the candy itself is pretty darn delightful! But $10 for 8 pieces.. gah!! I don't know the history of these candies, but it was the first time I came across it so it was a must try. My sister did try to hunt for them again when we were in SF. Very interesting indeed though.
author: Yannie S.

description: I grew up eating this in Taiwan. I find theirs too much powder/flour. Nevertheless, it's a fun treat if you've never tried it!
author: Stacey L.

description: This place is amazing. The Dragon Beard candy is really good! It's like candy floss but it doesn't melt, isn't sticky, and it's stringy! They have a lot of flavors to choose from as well! If you are ever in Chinatown, I suggest that you check out this awesome place!
author: Gd4e Y.

description: Absolute delight! Wasn't sure what to expect when I was casually passing by china town. Such a tiny spot easy to miss. What caught our eye was a man making these and got exited to get in. We did not regret it. Absolutely delicious. My kinda candy -- not overly sweet but just the right amount. I recommend strawberry
author: Faizneen B.

description:
Stumbled upon Dragon Papa with a friend last night after finding, to our disappointment, that the owners of Golden Gate Bakery had once again taken an indefinite vacation with no end date specified (why?!). 

Well, we're so glad that we happened upon Dragon Papa! The molasses-wrapped candy mirrors what I had as a kid in Hong Kong. Neatniks be warned: It's true that enjoying the stringy candy means developing messy "dragon beard" as the string hangs off of your chin and face. Moreover, your clothes will receive a magical sprinkling of the magic Dragon Papa powder. 

That said, for my friend and me, the messiness actually made the process of trying the candies that much more fun! We tried the mango and original flavors, and I personally prefer the original; the taste of the mango seemed a bit artificial, whereas the original was as the candy was meant to taste. 

The only reason Dragon Papa falls short of the full five stars is its price point. For a small box of eight candies, you pay $11, which is relatively steep if you consider alternative on-the-go dessert options in Chinatown. Imho, however, the $11 was definitely worth at least a first taste!
author: Ada W.

description: Really delicious and interesting treat! Glad we tried it!! Very cool to watch them making it it, too. That inspired us to go inside to see what they were making.
author: Anne M.

description:
I was attracted to this place because they bring me back to my memory eating the Mochi-peanut (Muah Chee); a childhood snack I had growing up in Singapore, and now missing it. 

The store was a real tiny snack shop, no seating, this is more of get-it-to-go places. The atmosphere was friendly, however, with the owner being so happy to engage us in conversation. Dragon Papa emphasize on just about two items; the beard candy and the mochi with peanuts. We got both. 

The mochi was about $5, and it was delicious! Glutinous  rice cake, steamed, cut and coated generously with sugar, peanuts and sesame seeds, chewy and kinda addicting. We also got the beard candy in strawberry flavors, $9 (since the owner suggested that was his fave.), it was okay, I didn't like it as much... I thought it was pretty chalky and the candy was too sticky for my liking. 

I would certainly be back for the Mochi, delicious and rare Asian street snacks that fulfill (somewhat) my craving for my beloved childhood snacks.
author: Veronica C.

description: It was worth the show but not the dessert we were looking for.
author: Steven M.

description: delicious desserts that are handmade and always made fresh! the mochi is AMAZING. A little pricey but well worth it since there's no other place like this in california!
author: Serena W.

description: It was pretty seeing them make this dessert, but it was like 11$ for 6! So I'm guessing it's take a long time just to make. I was too cheap to try it and I already had desert before I saw dragon Papa lol.
author: Jc J.

description:
I found this place on Yelp and was in Chinatown so I figured I'll give it a try, especially since the pictures looked really interesting. 

Location: 
This place is literally a hole in the wall so it can be easily missed. They have a glass window right at the front showing you how they make it, so that helped the store stand out in the mist of all the shops around it. 

Service: 
The guy at the register was super friendly and helpful. He was explaining to us the difference between the "dragon beard" and cotton candy that most people mistaken it for. He also gave us a sample of the mango candy that they also sell (it tasted exactly like mango-flavored sugar). 

Mango and Strawberry Dragon Beard: 
The taste is very subtle. I tasted more of the peanut filling than the dragon beard. It has a thread-like feeling to it, hence it is not like cotton candy but it melts like cotton candy. It reminded me a lot of the Vietnamese peanut candy snack as it was very sticky and chewy. It might come off as too sweet for other people but as a sugar addict, I thought it was good. 

Overall: 
This is something I would get once in awhile, especially for it's novelty.
author: Annie V.

description: What a find... walking thru Chinatown and came across this gem! It looks kind of like cotton but the taste is amazing! I recommend the strawberry flavor soo  yummy....
author: Christina R.

description: Just ok. Too expensive but I suppose reasonable prices for tourists. We hard the regular and coffee flavor. The coffe flavor tasted a little artificial. I would would just stick to the original or try another flavor.
author: Margaret H.

description:
Awesome does not describe these rolls. Not only are they rate and made in only 3 places, but they are delicious! We paid for another Uber just to come back for more of these treats during our stay. The owner is very friendly and is happy to explain their history.
Come enjoy the messy!
author: Zach S.

description: Price is quite high $10 for a pack of candy but this is the only place you can find this candy made from scratch.  You may find this candy in an Asian grocery store for a cheaper price but taste maybe slightly different.
author: Simon C.

description: Great experience especially after seeing so many YouTube videos on this delicate dessert. It was quite good and not too sweet. I got the original flavor.
author: Linda X.

description: Finally got to try this place! after seeing it so much on Instagram, I came out to SF to give it a go. Its definitely not what you expect or something you think you ever had in your life. the texture is different but in a good way. Fluffy, floury, and turns into a hard gummy once melted in your mouth. I would say go for the Green tea flavor, they actually capture the tea flavor very well. I wasn't a fan of the filling so I ended up just unwrapping it and eating the candy by itself. Overall, its a good try of something new. If I could buy it without the filling I would go again.
author: Khaye S.

description:
I'm from Hong Kong so when I see Asian/Hong-Kong style snacks, I go for it. And I have high standards.

Dragon Papa Dessert made me feel like I was in Asia. I've always loved the combination of peanut and coconut. Texture and fineness was powder, stringy and sugary and flavor balance was on point. Extremely delicate and you can observe the process of how it was made too. There were other flavors like coffee, strawberry and mango which I thought was a little bit strange - I just like to stick to the original. 

Nice place, definitely stop by if you're looking for a taste of Hong Kong desserts.
author: Nicholas Y.

description: I'm always so amazed  of Chinese history .. this is an artisan art of candy making .  This art has been passed on Thru generations  and this is not something you learn overnight... it's very labor intensive and it just brings you back in time .. this dessert was only made for the emperors  and to have it survived all these years is amazing...coming from Asian tradition this is something to be proud of .... my favorite is the the traditional, and the mochi ... it's pricey but well worth it ... you can't find this anywhere else so when I visit  San Francisco this is always the place I go to ..
author: Dee M.

description:
tl;dr: If you're looking for an adult version of cotton candy then this is it! $9 for 8 pieces of the original. It's not too sweet and has a wonderful texture. 

On the expensive side (other places I've been to only cost $4 a box). This is traditionally a Hong Kong candy where they spin threads of sugar and weave it around a cocoon of coconut, sesame and peanuts. Make sure you don't have a nut allergy! They also sell ginger chews and strawberry, mango or coffee versions of their dragon beard candy ($10). If you've never had it then you should definitely try it!
author: Carrie X.

description:
Finally stopped by today to get some dragon beard candy for my BF's and my parents. I remember having these when I was in elementary school during Chinese New Years and haven't had them since! So I was ecstatic when one opened in in Chinatown! Although traveling through busy SF downtown and pushing through tourist crowd to get here a tad of a hassle, it was worth it nonetheless :) Anything for some nostalgic sweets!  

SERVICE: 
own by a Chinese family! You'll see the dad making the dragon beard candy in front of the shop and the son selling on the inside. Although it was quite busy, the son took his time to acknowledge his guess. 

FOOD:
Dragon Beard Candy is pretty much a sweet peanut mix wrapped with thin strands of malt syrup (a little stronger than cotton candy texture). It gets quite messy to eat because of the flaky texture, but also melts a little in your mouth. It taste as good as I remembered it to be! :) I think the price is reasonable since it's pretty rare to find nowadays (8 piece box for $9). They also sell mochi and ginger candy. 

AMBIANCE: 
Very smalls shop, but well lit and decently clean. 

Overall, I would come back to get more for family or friends who have missed these candies!
author: Samantha F.

description:
This gem is literally in the strip of Chinatown and im so glad I stopped to be amazed by the way they handmade the candy right in the front window. It's so amazing how they stretch the candy and how the candy melts in your mouth. The family that owns this business are sweethearts too. 
A box of dragon's beard is $10 I believe, but trust me.. it's worth trying. But make sure to eat it within that day because the candy doesn't taste the same when you leave it there for a couple of days
author: Holly V.

description: I love this cute litttle shops. I like looking for the dragon candy in festives, I'm glad they have a actual shop I can go to when I want some rather waiting for a festive and looking for it. Love the little candy rocks on the counter. Lots of different flavors, green tea, coffee, mango, strawberry and more other ones.
author: Paulie L.

description: Delicious!! Bring back lots of childhood memories. Original is not very sweet. Green tea is very frangance. They also have strawberry, mango and coffee. I'll be back to try other favor.
author: Grace N.

description: This is the first time I've tried this type of candy. At first it looks very stringy, almost like-hair. Pretty much, it is a very authentic hand-pulled sugar dessert. This candy literally melts in your mouth and it was amazing! The best part is, all Dragon Beard Candy here is handmade. You can see a live demo at the front of the store of how it is made. The Dragon Beard Candy comes in several different flavors. You have the option to buy a full box of 8 or half a box. I would definitely recommend.
author: Emily Y.

description: Expensive but SO worth it!! Love their traditional and coffee flavored beard candy. It's unique and you can't get anything like it in SF. Definitely worth a try! Just melts in your mouth
author: Alexandra T.

description: This is a must try authentic Chinese candy. I haven't seen it since I was a kid and it's more than 20 years. I got the strawberry favor and the taste is awesome! The peanuts inside are so fresh and sweet is just fine, the texture is so unique and not really same as cotton candy. Definitely I will come back Chinatown for this special pastry as the Christmas gift ~~!
author: Hayley W.

description: Curiosity drew me to this tiny store in China Town as I walked by and saw someone in the glass window pulling sugar.  The sugar was really fine like strands of hair, but thinner.  I stepped into the store and saw two women wrapping the strands of sugar around a little piece of candy by hand.  The process is tedious which makes this candy much more appreciated.  I love that the candy is not made with a machine.  The best way is to pop it into your mouth and let the sugar melt a little and begin to chew.  The center is soft and chewy flavored with sesame seed, chopped peanuts and I think a hint of coconut.  Some people think the price is steep for a box, but seeing the labor that goes into each hand rolled treats is worth the price.
author: Sweetie G.

description:
I really tried to appreciate the dragon beard candy, I think it is unusual and different from anything I have tried. Apparently you can eat it two different ways: the regular way (the way they sell it in stores), or you can put it in the fridge for it to harden. I wish I had access to a fridge, or I bet this would have been wonderful.
 The taste was great, however be prepared to have powder all up in your nose because it is so messy! You will have a sneeze attack.
author: Sabryna L.

description:
This shop is tucked away in Chinatown and you can miss it easily. It is a tiny shop selling a cool pulled sugar dessert. If you have nut or coconut allergies - not the place for you! 

The dessert is messy but fun and melts into a chewy toffee/taffy thing in your mouth. It's full of peanut butter and coconut flaves.
author: Shelley K.

description: Dragon's Beard Candy has been on my list of must-try desserts for years. After finding Dragon Papa Dessert on Yelp, my boyfriend and I made our way here to finally try the infamous Dragon's Beard Candy. We arrived at opening and was welcomed in by one of the workers. An older woman, who I assume is the owner, greeted us kindly and immediately began helping us. She was very sweet and asked how we found out about her candy. We ended up purchasing the matcha and original flavored candies - both were delicious! While the price ($10-$11 per box) is a bit high for a small box of desserts, it was well worth it. I think it should also be considered that the process of making the candy is laborious. I will definitely come here again!
author: Lana B.

description: Not many places you can get dragon beard candy's anymore! Especially not in NY, so being able to randomly walk by here and buying a few boxes definitely reminded my gf and I about when we were younger. What's there not to love, the "dragonbeard Miastro" is the apprentice of the original master that originated with his first stall in chinatown NY. He's as legit as it can be.
author: Dennis K.

description:
The best days are the childhood days - the days we can't get back. When I found out these candy existed, it brought back lots of childhood memories! It was when my family and I lived in SF, and my mom would bring back snacks that I thought were weird looking, from Chinatown including these! 

I decided to drive to downtown (week SB50 began) and it was packed!! I walked through the tunnels and to Grant Ave. Found this little whole in the wall - the store is like a narrow closet & a bit hard to miss - and was welcomed by the view of someone making the dragon beard. I entered and there were a few boxes stacked, so I grabbed about 3-4 (souvenirs for my NOLA friends). 

These little candy are about 2 inches tall probably, 8 pieces in one box, and $9 for one box. Quite expensive, so I hope you savor the taste! The dragon beard looks like a little cocoon and when you bite into it, the dragon beard will melt in your mouth and you will suddenly be tasting nuts. I think this candy is very unique because I haven't seen it elsewhere, and as other reviewers wrote, it is a dying art. The store also offers other stuff, I don't remember since I didn't pay much attention to the board - but I do know there are ginger candies! Reading from another review, there will be flavored dragon beard candies soon perhaps... ;) 

Definitely something to try if you are in Chinatown. You probably can't find these elsewhere, and if you do, it's probably hard!
author: Mandy G.

description:
Did someone say Chinese candy?!?!

It has been forever since I had some Dragon Beard candy, and if I must say so myself, these were amazing! Not only is it delicious, it is a part of Chinese culture and history which makes it just that much better. And to make things even better they actually perform the stretching of the candy in a display window at the front of the store, which attracts attention. Thus, adding that "WOW!" factor. 

The candies are sold in a small little box filled with 8 pieces for $9, which is quite expensive in my eyes but totally worth it considering how much art goes into each and every one of them. So my best advice would be to savor each and everyone of them until tears draw from your eyes! In terms of taste it really hits the spot because the crushed peanuts aren't too sweet which is a good thing because the pulled candy threads are already sweet enough.   

Overall, if you want to try some really delicious old-school Chinese candy then this is the place where it is at! These candies are a wonderful gift for friends and families that love sweets and peanuts.
author: Benson M.

description: So good.... In fact.... we are going back to get more.  It's not cheap, but it's so worth it..... I think this is laced... just a joy to eat....
author: Elle E.

description: We stopped into this tiny, unassuming place on a whim and boy were we impressed! These painstakingly made candies are fantastic. Not too sweet they are both nutty and chewy and dragon beard messy but delicious. It's an authentic stop in China town that you won't regret.
author: Mark A.

description:
Fresh original flavor is the best.  Derek is the fifth generation of making this kind of candy. 
Coffee flavor is good too
author: m m.

description: I am So glad we stopped here. It's a tiny place and there were 4 people hand-making these desserts. The lady that helped us was a sweet little lady. We bought a box that had original and strawberry. I wish I would've bought the coffee flavor too but I had no idea how good these would be. They just melt in your mouth. We put them in the fridge which I really liked them cold. They aren't to sweet and have a nice nutty flavor. I will definitely be back if I'm back in San Francisco.
author: Jenna G.

description: The very best confection in Chinatown. Sweet hand pulled cotton candy wrapped with nuts, melts in your mouth. The plain is simply wonderful and the other flavors of strawberry, mango and coffee ad to the wonderfulness of this ancient delicacy, a must try. I pick up a container overtime I'm in Chinatown
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
I got the original flavor. It tasted nutty and delicately sweet without being too overpowering. The texture of the candy was unique. 

Watching the process of hand creating the beard candy was fascinating. 

A guy at the counter educated us that the beard candy was traditionally for emperors, and that there were only a handful of places in US that still make those with their hands. The whole experience was worth it.
author: Mary K.

description:
This is a small shop that is family owned.  It's so small that if you walked too fast, you'll miss it.   In the front of the store behind the glass window, you can view someone making the dessert.  Everyone working wore gloves.  There were two other ladies inside making the dessert too.  One bad thing was as one of the ladies finished making a Dragon Beard's candy, she placed it into her mouth while wearing her gloves and ate the candy in front of us.  That was not cool!  She didn't even change her gloves afterwards.  

The elder lady is very nice and she's the one to handle the sales.

The Dragon Beard's candy was pretty good.  Be careful when you put it into your mouth, the thin strands of the candy can drop off and spill on your clothing.  You have to eat the whole thing all at once.  The store has toothpicks available for you to eat the candy with.

I'm giving 3 stars for the taste of the candy.  The candy is expensive to me so it's a treat for me.

 - 8 small pieces for $10 for the original/regular flavor which is the white ones.  
 - 8 pieces for $11 for other flavors (mango or strawberry). 

I've eaten this candy before in LA and it was sweeter and with more fillings. 

They also have mochi with sesame seeds.  A small tiny (and I mean tiny) container is $5.00.  The texture of the mochi is soft and chewy.
author: J W.

description:
The first time I tried Dragon Beard Candy was in China. I remember the street vendor made it upon order and it was super fluffy, soft and melts in your mouth. 

This is a messy snack so don't try to eat it in your car or anywhere with carpet, unless you are skilled at stuffing large items into your mouth. ; ) 

The Dragon Beard Candy wasn't as magical as I remembered it but it is still pretty good. 

Minus one star for being priced at $9 for 8 pieces but it is worth a try if you have never had it before.
author: Winnie T.

description:
I stumbled upon this store while walking around Chinatown.  I'm so glad I stopped in.  Their original candy was super fun to eat.  You have to eat it within couple days because it will turn hard.  It is only fun to eat when it is still soft and fresh.  I first tried this candy when I was in Hong Kong back in 2011.  I'm happy that they brought this over to Cali.

It takes a lot of work just to make one single candy.  Which it make sense for their prices on these candies.  Give it a try.  If you are allergic to peanuts, this is not for you.  It is filled with lots of peanuts!
author: Susan B.

description: Love this homemade old Chinese recipe candy!!  Well worth the stop get some next time you are in San fran
author: Wendy M.

description:
This place is known for their "beard" candy. The texture is super interesting. The inside filling is made out of ground peanuts and it's wrapped with this special sugar that has a string-like texture. It's quite messy to eat, and the sugar strings end up sticking to your lips (hence why it's called beard candy). It is tasty though, I'm just not a huge fan of peanuts! I've never heard of this candy before, but apparently it was traditionally served as a royal snack back in ancient China.

I wish you could buy them individually, but they only sell them in boxes of 8, AND they don't offer samples, so there's really no way for you to try it out and decide if you like it or not. I probably won't be coming back, but I'm happy I gave it a try!
author: Ashley Y.

description: This family business (with a very personable nephew who teaches customers about the art) offers some of the most unique candy I've ever had. It's not too sweet, even though the thin threads are stretched from molasses. It's puffy when you bite into it, and then it becomes perfectly gooey as you chew. I bought the original and green tea. I prefer the original (which really doesn't taste much different at all) because of the more pronounced change of texture. The green tea one does not get very chewy. I'm going back tomorrow to pick some up as souvenirs.
author: Anna A.

description: Such an awesome spot! Best dragons beard I've had (original is my personal favorite) and the owner is so kind too. It's a family business at its fifth generation, support local!
author: Christe'An I.

description: This is amazingly delicious. This place is a gem. The dragon beard is considered as art and it is long loss handcraft candy from back in the days. Would definitely come back.
author: BT B.

description: I saw many reviews about this place and have been dying to try it. It was a little hard to find because it was a tiny shop. The lady and her husband was very friendly and helpful. I got the mango, coffee and the original one. The mango one was a tad bit to sweet for me. Coffee was a little to bitter, but was still good. The regular one was amazing, not to sweet or bitter. The way they make it is really cool and I expected the candy to be harder, but it melted in my mouth.
author: Irene Z.

description:
Ok if you've ever tried these, you have to grab some! I've been so sad that they stopped making these at the Honolulu Downtown Chinese New Year celebration. It's like a dying art so when you can get some....buy!
It's not a cheap sweet but it's handmade and fresh. The owner makes it right in the little window for people to watch. I believe it was his son inside who talked with us regarding the candy process and how long it lasts. The stringy cotton candy puff has a sweet nutty, coconut taste that I love! 
When I return to San Francisco for another visit, I'm definitely returning. I'm so happy that when we were leaving, we got a number of passerbys interested. Who doesn't like helping out small family businesses right?!
author: LO N.

description:
Hello Yelpers!

Once upon a time there lived a dragon who lived high in the sky. He flew happily as his long white silky beard trailed behind him. Often, strands of his beard would fall out and create light fluffy clouds. When a cloud would form the dragon would cry for joy. Sometimes those tears would touch the clouds and produce rain. Farmers' crops would grow and rivers would flow. The people living underneath the sky would be grateful. To celebrate their symbiotic relationship the people created Dragon Beard Candy. 

[THE STORY IS A WORK OF FICTION BY ME]

The candy is created by father and son. The lightly sweet, soft, and chewy candy is filled with peanuts. The combination of the chewy beard and the crunchy peanuts is perfect. I would more say it's a pastry than a candy. Either way you call it, it's delicious!

Pros:
1) Soft and chewy
2) Light and crunchy
3) Lightly sweetened
4) Delicious
5) Wonderful service

Cons:
1) Limited supply.
2) Only peanut filling. They should try using almond filling for those that have peanut allergy to expand their clientele.

Happy Dragon Beard!
author: Edward K.

description:
Dragon Papa has been catching some fire lately in SF! It's a hot and new business on Yelp and was recently featured on the SF Chronicle (http://www.sfchronicle.com/food/article/Chinatown-s-Dragon-Papa-turns-candy-making-into-6540529.php) This shop used to operate as a booth in the dim sum behemoth, Koi Palace, in Daly City and has since branched out to expand their reach.

FOOD:  I've only tried their flagship dessert, the Dragon Beard Candy, but Dragon Papa does also offer Ginger Candy and Mochi. On the exterior, the Dragon Beard Candy looks like Kellogg's Frosted Mini Wheats (or a white cocoon or mini pillow) decorated with white wispy silk-like threads of sugar. This airy outer layer dissolves in your mouth like cotton candy. If you want a crunchier shell, apparently you can also refrigerate the candy. The core of the candy is filled with crushed peanut, coconut, and sesame seeds. Altogether, the combination of the melty exterior and crumbly interior gives the candy a chewy taste. 

SERVICE: The owner is really friendly and takes the time to introduce you to Dragon Beard Candy. We had a nice conversation about the history of the candy and his store. There isn't  much of a seating area in this shop, but that's the norm for some  dim sum shops/bakeries around the area.

LOCATION: Dragon Papa is located on Grant Avenue, one of Chinatown's main and oldest streets. If you enter Chinatown from the Dragon's Gate and continue walking down that pathway you'll eventually come across this store. Also take sometime to enjoy the murals and sculptures of terra cotta warriors located right above the shops in this vicinity.

PRICE: The Dragon Beard Candy is $9 for a box of 8 candies. While the cost may seem quite high, I think the pricing is appropriate considering that candy making is a laborious and dexterous process. Currently they only accept cash.

DISCLAIMER: Some of the pictures of the plated candy were taken off-site.
author: Anthony S.

description:
These. Are. SOOOOO. BOMB. Holy just writing this review makes me regret not buying more :(
They're a little pricey, 8 pieces for $9 (original) $10 (mixed or flavored) but they are worth. They take time to prepare and make these small delicious things.
It's basically this spun sugar wrapped around crushed peanuts. It melts in your mouth into this toffee like texture. I tried the original and the mango flavors and they were so good! 
Also pretty good service for a small hole in the wall place in the heart of China town ! The guy was super friendly and warned us it would be messy to eat (it really was) and the old guy was also really nice :)
I had to go back to buy a second package... but I regret not buying more.
Even my family whom I shared with loved it, and they usually don't like sweets !
These treats are so unique and I haven't seen anything like them anywhere else... maybe in China but no where around here :(
I didn't even have time to take a picture because I was too busy eating them up haha. Next time I'm here I'm buying every flavor.
author: Gabriella T.

description:
I am impressed it is delicious and reminds of Hong Kong. This is a specialized craft to make this candy and is a dying art. Even in Hong Kong it is hard to find. 

The crunchy peanut filling, the light crumbly spun sugar strands, with a hint of sweetness is so good! I wipe the crumbs from the bottom of my empty box. 
While it seems expensive (box of 8 for $9; macaroons are just as expensive--averaging $2 apiece), the labor involved making the candy is worth the price to me.  
I don't shop in Chinatown, but when I do, I make it a point to buy a box. The candy stores well in the fridge and will last for more than a month. On my last visit, I was told that they will be introducing new flavors...strawberry, mango & coffee. I can't wait to get a box mango flavored candy.
author: Kathy L.

description: The candy beard and the peanut mochi here is a must try.The price for the candy is a bit over priced ,but definitely worth it.Loved eating these as a child and having it here in San Francisco is great for me.The candy is not too sweet and not too savory from the peanuts.Hope they don't close down, will always come back to buy more.
author: Elle B.

description: What an exquisite dessert! You MUST have one of these!! If you're going to bother to check out Chinatown in San Francisco, then you should definitely stop in here. Right on Grant Street, you can't miss it. My family and I happened upon this little storefront and boy, am I glad we did! I now make everyone I know that plans on visiting San Francisco stop in.
author: Coco T.

description:
Loved this dessert on the streets of Hong Kong.  So excited that this family is keeping this dying
Art of making dragon beard candy alive and in San Francisco .  It is not cheap but so labor intensive that it is worth every bite.  Also amazed how long it stays fresh when kept air tight and in the fridge.  Easy to miss if you walked to fast on grant avenue !
author: MJ C.

description:
I see this place as a novelty that will not last. This father and son shop selling the dragon beard candy takes more than 10 minutes to make from scratch. They sell them for $9 for a small tray of 8, which is  the price of a typical meal in Chinatown. The beard candy is just something that someone would buy to try, has not special or wonderful flavors. 

Then the ginger candy which is common in HK they are selling for $3 a bag has little to any ginger in it. The bag is the size of tampon. 

And for their price, they only accept cash.
author: M C.

description: Wow!! Feels like I'm back in Singapore. ...they are a family owned little candy store. They make everything right there by hand. You have to go and try the dragon beard candy...
author: Pat N.

description: Was in the area and didn't expect to find this gem. This is such a treat as I had this when I was a kid and couldn't find it anymore. I got the original flavor. Just got one box to try and am regretting not buying more. It was expensive ($10 per box of 8 candies). The flavor was peanuty sesame goodness. Just the right amount of sweetness.  Will be back for more when I am in town.
author: Jenny T.

description: Definitely a worthwhile delicacy! The gentleman inside was very helpful and kind. I've heard of this candy before and knew that it was rare as the guy did say that it doesn't really exist in L.A. or NY atm. Yes, it costs $9 for 8 pieces but well worth the money. It's not just any piece of candy. In my opinion, it's like the Chinese version of baklava. As others mentioned, the outside strings melt in your mouth and the robust peanut filling inside is very yummy and not overly sweet. Very cool to see the window display of hand-making the candies. Each one tasted so fresh even after bringing them back to Chicago for about a week. I wish I bought more!!!
author: Amanda M.

description: I love the Dragon Beard candy!!  It was my 1st time ate 6 (box of 8 pieces) within hour.  Original and green tea flavor are the best!!  The elder lady told me that keep it in the refrigerator for up to one month.
author: Desiree H.

description: The candy is delicious and so is their mochi. But it is super overpriced. The reason why I bought the dragon candy is because a friend of mine told me that they are the only place in China town that sells it which is probably why it's expensive. It would be helpful to know Cantonese when you go in the store but pointing works too.
author: M B.

description:
Nice place! Super mom and pop style - but more like son and pop style. The man behind the window is "papa." The son works inside the stores selling warm mochi candy covered in sesame roasted peanuts. Definitely delicious and one of a kind of you like mochi and peanuts. He also has a freeze friend ginger candy that I have never had before. I only like ginger on my sushi, but damn this candy is super good. It's got a nice spice tingle on the end that I have never experienced with any other type of "bittersweet" candy. Finally the dragon beard candy looks insane! I have never seen anything like it and will give it a taste as soon as I crack the package open. There were no samples because only a very limited amount of candies are made per day (totally understandable).

Last but not least the son was very nice. He gave up a break down of how the candy is made and how he has been with his dad in this shop since its inception. 

I will definitely come back here to visit next time in I'm SF!
author: Henry S.

description:
I love how they have a display window where you can observe how the dessert is made. The pastry chef himself stands in the front making the white covering which is quite entertaining to watch. He uses a piece of what seems like pretzel dough and keeps pulling it with flour until it becomes this almost weightless thin strands of yummy goodness and fills it with peanut and sesame. 

I haven't tried the other fruity flavors but I dont usually prefer fruity Chinese candy. The sesame and peanut filled dragon beard candy literally melts in your mouth the moment you bite into it and the sesame and peanut filling is chewy. 

First time trying it and it was a winner.
author: Joanne K.

description: This place is a hole in the wall but awesome and authentic ! I definitely recommend going here if you want to try an extraordinary dessert in Chinatown
author: Jasmine S.

description: The dragon beard candies are not common finds, probably even in HK, and especially if you're looking for a place that specializes in them and makes them in front of you. Apparently the proprietor used to work at Koi Palace at Daly City and has since opened his own place here. I think this is pretty neat since aiming the market toward tourists does raise awareness of this rare snack. The prices are admittedly a bit expensive, although I'm sure the labor in making them is not easy and they have a monopoly for the time being anyway, so they can charge whatever they want. The other thing is that I hope that they will eventually offer more flavors like they used to at Koi Palace, probably after they get things going and hire more help or stabilize their revenues.
author: Tony D.

description:
This place is a gem! These candies are made in the traditional way - painstakingly hand pulled sugar into very fine strands, then carefully wrapped around chopped peanuts and sesame. This type of candy is rarely made nowadays. This is only the second time I have come across them.  

I picked up two boxes of original flavor. My kids LOVED them! They also sell flavored ones - strawberry, mango, and chocolate, which I plan to stock up on as well. They last 3 months in the fridge.
author: Jenny C.

description: I was walking in SF and saw this little shop.. stopped by to watch the way they hand make the candys. So I had to buy each flavor to try, cofffee mango and original. They all taste amazing. U can really taste the flavors in each of them. I put it on snap chat and a friend of mines actually wanted me order some and ship it to her because a lot of Chinese places do not make them anymore ! Chinese delicacy!
author: Dip N.

description: I haven't had dragon whisker candy before, but I've always wanted to. You can watch a lady work her magic from the outside of the store, which is pretty cool. The owner or worker there was very friendly. He explained the candy history and the different sweetness level for each flavor. We got two boxes (original and coffee) and it came out to be $19.00.  I enjoyed the peanuty taste and the sweetness level of the coffee flavor. I don't like my desserts to be super sweet. They were also very clean, which I appreciated.
author: Kosmo Z.

description:
Really friendly and extremely clean shop! The candy was light, delicate and delicious.

It is pretty pricey for the candy but definitely worth it!
author: Jenna U.

description:
Walk all the way down to Chinatown to give them a try!! finally got to try this out! 
there aint that much dragon beard candy in the bay area.
$9 - 8 pieces of them
The beard wont stick inside the teeth and the peanuts & sugar inside isnt that sweet which makes u fall in love to eat more.
The candy itself feels like a bit crunchy.
Will definitely come back for more as dessert if im near the area.
author: Kalum Z.

description: Such a unique, fun and yummy find in Chinatown! Loved watching them make the candy and then loved the eating the candy even more. It's a must for Chinatown!
author: Cameron H.

description: One of the most unique desserts I've ever had. The candy looks like thread or flooss rolled up with a chewy peanut inside. They also have different flavors to the candy. I had strawberry it was not too sweet but had the pure taste or strawberry and was not too overpowering. Cute little stand and the cashier was really friendly
author: James V.

description: Great traditional Chinese dessert that you can't find anywhere else. Highly recommended and must try!
author: Ming X.

description: Great employees. The front desk guy was super nice and informative. Place is clean. It's not a dessert I'd suddenly crave randomly but if I was in the Chinatown area in SF, and with friends who've never seen or tried this dessert, id come back. My son loves it and always asks for the "sticky beard treat".  Truly an interesting shop to visit!
author: Walerz B.

description: A true "mom & pop" that is not only a celebration of a dying art, but also some of the best and most complex candies to come out of the East. It's a rare treat that is not easily found fresh in many Asian countries today. It's definitely worth the try.
author: Mike H.

description:
Chinese "cotton candy" with peanuts and sesame seeds on the inside. Absolutely love.

This brings back childhood memories. It may seem expensive but I will pay whatever it takes to keep this kind of artisanal Asian food alive. I hope the older gentleman gets a chance to pass on his skills to a younger person who wants to keep this forever alive. And seriously if you compare these prices to anything non Asian you're getting a deal at about 1/pc. Understand the labor of love that went into each pc.

Just like handmade noodles :( down the street don't know where that older gentleman went. It's a very sad thing.
author: Lily V.

description: Saw them making these delicious treat in the window. Had to stop in and try. This is made with peanuts . Definitely must try
author: Stefanie F.

description: This place is amazing! Love finding spots that make unique items. It's a tiny shop but it's quick and easy to purchase items when on the go. Since it was my first time I just ordered the original. Powdery, flossy, very lightly sweetened cotton candy texture on the outside and a peanut, sesame seed, and coconut mixture on the inside. To die for!! Definitely going  back to try the other flavors and to get an order of the mochi.
author: Maggie R.

description: What not to love this traditional Chinese candy?  This is one of the candies that I grown up with, cute little treat with a lot of goodies inside.  You won't be disappointed.
author: E P.

description: AWESOME! Enthusiastic owners who shared their insight and a bit of a history lesson.  Watch the craftsmanship of the man in the window and then come in to buy the treat! Multiple flavors,  we got original and I loved it! Very nutty but not too sweet. Delicious!
author: Irene S.

description:
This is one of the transitional snack once was only served to the elite in the Tang Dynasty China. It tastes exactly same as one i had in Xi'an city.
You should not miss this because of the art work itself, the taste and the texture inside the mouth.
author: Rade M.

description: Wow this place is a must try! After having some awesome dim sum I continued my trek through china town. I swear I find something different every time I visit SF. Today I stumbled upon this little store with a guy in the window. So not knowing what's the deal I ventured inside. I was greeted by a gentleman who was super friendly. He explained to me that the candy was special . it was called dragon beard and consists of coconut, peanuts, and sesame seeds inside. The guy said I needed to be careful when I eat it jokingly. Today they only had the original flavor because it was so close to the new year. So I got me a box that ran about 9 bucks. On the way out I watched the old man in the window making the candy. It looks so amazing almost like he was making cotton candy but very dusty .Since I was wearing black I was going to wait to try when I got home. Good thing I did my first bite was like a puff of dust. It was pretty damn good I would say. I'm not sure about the mess it made on my lips but good things can make you a little dirty at times. I will totally have to recommend anyone in the area give this place a try. I believe they are the only ones in the bay making it.
author: Tony B.

description: Owner of this place is a 5th generation person to make beard candies. Apparently this delicacy is a dying art in China/Hong Kong and is very rare to find there.  How cool it is to find this out here in San Francisco. Original flavored beard candies are really tasty and is a must buy if you like the nutty taste.
author: K D.

description: Strangely addicting candy in its own way. Bought some to bring back to family. Must try if you want something different.
author: Andy N.

description: Fresh dragon beard candy, definitely a delicacy! Light & flavorful, not too sweet. A small family business that offers up friendly service.
author: Judy Y.

description:
Not many places sell these anymore since there's not many people who even know how to make this special dessert! I live in LA and there was an old man who made these in the LA Chinatown, but he has since retired. Thus, my mom and I were super excited to see this young asian guy making these from a small window in the SF Chinatown! Super unexpected! 

While some people think the box of dragon beard candy for $9 is expensive, it's pretty reasonable considering it is a recipe and craft passed down for generations. The young man is the owner and makes these candies as well as the mochi and ginger candy fresh each day. The old man is his dad and the one who trained him. 

Anyway, I really like to support small businesses run by families so I bought both the dragon beard candy and the mochi. Both were delicious!! The mochi was still warm and not covered in sugar like in other places. The dragon beard candy reminds me of the kind I would eat in Hong Kong when I was little and it just melts in your mouth! 

I would highly recommend that you try this place out!! It's a small hole in the wall, but it's really clean inside. They do accept credit card and not just cash only. Hurry and go grab a box!
author: Michelle C.

description:
This place a delicious!  This is the closest to the ones they make in Hong Kong on the streets. It's amazing watching them stretch the thin strands of sugar and not breaking. I love that this sweet treat is actually not as sweet as it looks. The peanuts add a wonderful saltiness to the sugar and it's a match made in heaven! 
Just keep an eye out when looking for this place. It's a tiny little window and if you walk too fast, you might just miss it.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Super cool place to get candy, love that you can watch in the front and see how it's made!
author: Michelle C.

description:
There was an article about this place in the SF Chronicle.  A small store located in the heart of Chinatown and you can watch them making this candy dessert.  My first time trying this dessert candy and my first thoughts were this is interesting and quite expensive.  $9. for 8 pieces.

My first bite was......... it was absolutely delicate and delicious...not too sweet...just perfection with each bite.  Original flavor was good and take note:  be careful when you eat it as the peanuts fall out when tilted.  

I'm a fan and would recommend treating yourself to a royal dessert.
author: Nanana A.

description: Tastes good but not worth $10.00 (plus taxes). If you are looking for dessert just go to the Chinese bakery next door.
author: Camila C.

description: These candies are not only super yummy but they are a work of art! Stop by SF's Chinatown and visit Dragon Papa's to watch the candy artist in the window turn a cup of hardened molasses into long strands of "dragon beard hair" which are then stuffed with a sesame peanut mixture. Buy extra boxes because we ended up eating our gifts and had to return to replace them before we headed back home! :)
author: Judy L.

description:
Today is one of my happiest days.  I have been searching for Dragon Beard candy for years and I didn't know where I can get it.  First, I didn't know what is called until today.  I just know what it looks like.  I love this candy since I was a child in China.  I had it in USA only three times in 40 years.  I am just way too happy to find this shop.  I was so excited and I couldn't stop telling anyone who would listen that how good this candy is.  I especially like that it's handmade.  Lots of work and talent put into it.  You got to try this candy.  However, if you are one of those people that is allergic​ to peanuts, then this is not for you.  Please, you must go and try it.  I will definitely go back again to get more.

****
I'd like to reply to M.C.'s negative review below. I do not agree with his review.  I certainly do not think this father and son deserve such negative review.  It's obviously M.C. doesn't know anything about making this type candy.  it certainly requires more than 10, 15 minutes.  To me, the price is worth it.  It's handmade, not like your everyday commercial candy filled with all kinds of the chemical.  

I am a big believer in support small mom and pop shop and hard working people.

By the way, I do not know the shop owners.  I've only met them today for the first time.
author: Butterfly S.

description: These are special because they are made before your eyes and absolutely impossible to believe. Delicate, light, and sweet! We got 8 for $10. I will be back for more! The original flavor I enjoyed more than the green tea, but both were amazing!
author: Laura P.

description: CAN'T believe my luck today coming across a review on my absolute childhood favorites from Hong Kong, the infamous dragon beard candies!!!  This yummy candy is so hard to make, it's even rare to see it in Hong Kong, let alone here in SF.  Get them while you can and support this sweet father & son team.  I had 1 that was freshly pulled by the father and it immediately melt in my mouth cuz it's that good.  The fillings are yummy roasted sesame, coconut & peanut.  There're other handmade candies like handmade ginger candies and mochis in the little shop to try as well...can't wait for my return visit :)
author: Stephanie C.

description:
As a inhabitant of Chinatown, I like to check out new food/drinks venue that props into the neighborhood. 

I noticed the former tea shop was gone and there was now an older gentleman hanging out in the open window procuring some type of concoction.  

One day, I finally decided to shuffle in out of curiosity.  
 
Gazing upon the small white board menu, I scanned the list of at most five items ranging from ginger candy, dragon beard candy, and peanut mochi balls. 
 
I wanted the peanut mochi balls, but they sold out for the day.  

I chose the dragon beard candy which looks like white cotton candy on the outside with peanut crumble in the middle. The white cotton candy had sticky consistency and was actually crunchy. Overall, it was interesting to eat and was still delectable.  

At $9 for a box of 8, this is definitely something I would get for friends to try, but not to eat regularly on my own.
author: Becky Q.

description: Very authentic, reminds me of the ones I ate in Hong Kong . Although a bit pricey at $9 a box but I'll say it's reasonable for it being so hard to find. It's literally a hole in the wall but it's clean.
author: Susan K.

description: amazing to see this team hon in with such dedication on their craft. I've had dragon candy from Toronto before but these guys are amazing. the owner is personable and fantastic at sharing the history and story behind this great delicacy. the dragon candy itself is fluffy and chewey with a really nice peanut filling. when I'm in town again I'll be sure to stop by.
author: Wil T.

description:
I originally saw the father/son tag team during the Moon Festival.

It's a dying art and one that can hopefully last.

As for the price, it was $9 for a box of 8 "artisan" handmade pieces :)

It's not very sweet and a bit dry. 

Eaten fresh, it sticks to my teeth. Out of the fridge, it's better in my view.

I hope this is a "stop" on the many walking tours that are in Chinatown.
author: Peter L.

description: Great dragon beard candy. Haven't had this in forever. Brings back old memories of my childhood in Oakland Chinatown. Definitely costs a lot more than back in the day. $9 for a small box with 8 pieces, but oh so good!
author: Cindy F.

description: The Stars tell it all. This place sure will become popular in no time. I wont be surprised to see a long line soon. Customer service is supra and the guy really took his time chatting with my parents. For large order, he recommended to place a phone order instead of walking in (for time sake). My parents and I sure will visit this place again in our next SF trip!
author: San Gabriel M.

description: The father and son team makes this absolutely delicious and fresh dessert! The only reason why I'm not giving them a full 5-stars is because they need an hour to prepare which is factored into their business hours. For example, we got there at 12 noon but they didn't open shop until 12:25pm (almost 1/2 hour late) and was told to come back an hour later because it takes them time to prepare it. Why not prep an hour earlier at 11am? We came back an hour later and there was already a line at the door, so in total we waited 2-hours. The wait was worth it but also a bit of an inconvenience.
author: Bill C.

description: If your visiting Chinatown, you need to come visit this unique store! You watch them make the candy, and it's truly artistic. And delicious! Original was our favorite flavor.
author: Reilly K.

description: Awesome! We tried the original and coffee flavors - literally finished off the box before we were out of the store. Although it was a little pricey, we couldn't resist buying another box. Kids loved it. Will go there again.
author: D N.

description:
Dragon Beard Candy...There is a man hand making this candy in the store front and it truly is an amazing to watch.  $9 for 8 pieces.  Small price to pay for a work of art.  Spun Sugar wrapped around peanut filling.  Yum!

If you've had Dragon Beard Candy at Koi Palace, I'm told by the man in the store that they're the same vendor.
author: Judy K.

description: Dragon Beard candy in Chinatown?! It's hard to find! My mom grew up eating this back in Hong Kong and it's actually the only place I've ever had it too. It's amazing and they make it fresh here! Definitely give it a try if you're ever in the area.
author: Jennifer H.

description: One of the rare dying art of Chinese candy making.   Dragon beard is a tasty morsel of pulled sugar that become sticky taffy in your mouth.  Glad to find it in San Fran!!!
author: shane c.

description: These are my absolute favorite when I was a kid and I am so ecstatic to find them just a few blocks from my office. Dragon Papa makes them just the way I remembered these delicate sweets. Sticky thin strands wrapping around these nice little crunchy pieces of peanuts, and just the right level of sweetness. Nom!
author: Nana L.

description:
Pretty cool novelty place. You can watch them make the dragon beard candy in front of you. I've never seen such a shop in Chinatowns before so it was a surprise to see one here. I've had dragon beard on one other occasion and it's not my cup of tea. However, you can purchase the candy by piece or set and there are 3 flavors. 

Would recommend to check out if you're in the area
author: Lily H.

description: Awesome experience! The dragon beard candy tastes exactly the same like the one I had in childhood. Thank you for bringing back the memory.
author: Jess F.

description: This candy/delicious treat is amazing at first it looks weird..very eye catchy..i just had to take like 4 boxes back to Bakersfield we came to vacay in San Francisco for the weekend...i HIGHLY RECOMMENDED THIS CANDY it's amazing!!!
author: Luis P.

description: Thank you for the helpful explanation, history, and for making a visit to this store a fun experience!
author: Sara P.

description: Derek's family has been making these desserts for 5 centuries. The shop is no frills; walk in, good chats, pick up your sweets and keep strolling along touristy Grant for a really lovely evening. #sfnative
author: M C.

description: This place sells authentic dragon beard candy!  Although I personally don't care for it at all, it does taste very authentic.  My wife who was originally from Taiwan has eaten it many times before and claims that the ones here are just as good if not better.  The dragon beard candy sold here consists of coconut, peanuts, and sesame seeds inside.
author: Steven L.

description: Dragon beard was amazingg I had  been waiting so long to one day try it and i got the chance today best trip ever
author: Jennifer P.

description: Love dragon beard candy! They finally opened a store front in chinatown. The mochi with toasted peanuts were good too.
author: Joy L.

description: Worth making a trip to try this delicious treat! Met Derek the owner who took the time to explain the labor intensive process. He told us that he is a 5th generation dragon beard sweet maker and only one other place in the US makes it. It is beautiful to watch the process and so tasty.
author: Moira O.

description:
There is not much selection and the prices are quite high. 

$9 for a box of dragon candy.

There is only one type of dragon beard candy and it has coconut, sesame seeds and peanuts. I am not really into the coconut part. The dragon beard candy at the Koi Palace in Daly City has more selection.
The mochi are soft but again $5 for a small box of mochi - like a slightly bigger than a credit card sized box.

I am all for supporting traditional dessert, but with those prices, I will have to support it more moderately.
author: July N.

description: $9 for a small box of Dragon candy may seem outrageous, but these candies are good & I can't find it anywhere else nearby, so I splurged on 2 boxes & didn't regret it. One downside is the store is small & the wait could take a while because the workers are quite chatty at times. Also, at times, the guy in the window can't make this stuff fast enough to accommodate all the demand. Not sure how long the novelty will last, but I'm enjoying it a lot right now.
author: Pham D.

description: When I found this place on Yelp during the weekend I was in San Fran, I knew I had to bring a box back to Seattle for my family and myself to try. The little grannie that helped me was so sweet and cute. Gahhh I just wanted to hug her. We were talking in Cantonese and I was telling her how I wanted to bring a box back for my mom to try since I know she'll love it. I bought a box of the original one and regret buying only one box :'( should have bought a few more and tried the flavored ones too.
author: Jamie L.

description:
This place makes "dragon beard candy" fresh!  Definitely a must try especially you won't be able to find this kind of candy elsewhere in the Bay Area.

Ginger candies taste better than the ones I get from Hong Kong!
author: Charles L.

description: The best candy I have ever tried, the sweetness is just fit and the chewy texture is kinda interesting. Definitely I will come back and get it~!
author: Maggie Y.

description: Bring back memories. The tradition candy from china are well made. Highly recommended. YE manager and Cheif are very nice.
author: Jay D.

description: Tasty traditional candy. Cute shop where you can watch them make the candy in the front window. They take credit card on one of the employees smart phones that has a square card reader. Anytime I go to China Town I will make a point of coming here :)
author: Sami Y.

description: I was watching the lady in the shop window making what i thought was really stringy noodles. I walk in and I ask the shop owner what she was making and he told me about Dragon Beard and how it was made. He also mentioned that there was only 3 places that he knew that made it. I tried the original and the coffee flavored and it was really good!! I dont recommend putting the whole thing in your mouth. Small bites for sure! Lol it reminded me of cotton candy consistency with peanuts inside. Really good stuff!
author: Cher F.

description: There is a fine line between art and food and this shop continuously blurs the lines between the two. We have been searching for years to find Dragons Beard in the Bay Area since we had it Vancouver many years ago but the search had always been fruitless. It was worth the search, the owners of this shop are incredibly nice and their product is superb. The candy is the perfect blend of flavors. Do yourself a favor, drop whatever you are doing and come out here for a once in a lifetime experience.
author: Huy H.

description: Dear lord - it's just like the ones sold in Hong Kong or Taiwan. It melts in your mouth and the people making it has been doing it for over two generations. Best I had in the States.
author: Edwin C.

description: I love the chewy texture and flavor of dragon bread peanut original flavor. This is one of kind desert I ever tasted. So if you ever decide to take an early lunch break and want something sweet, this is place to cured your sweet tooth, shop opens at 11am daily.
author: Ms R.

description: It's a super unique sweet. They make this cotton candy material into the texture of hair and stuff it with a sesame nut mix. They have different flavors. Friend said it looked like a mouse, but cool thing to try.
author: Matthew P.

description: This is not just candy.  This is candy ART! It is so delicious.  Worth every penny. Love, love,love!!!
author: Ronnie G.

description: This place is so good. It's a must try in Chinatown. The peanut tastes so good. Some people on Yelp suggested other flavors, like almond or walnut. Are you kidding me? The traditional dragon candy is only made with peanut. Stop Americanizing everything in the States. It's a traditional delicacy that's fading away slowly. It's $9 dollars for 8 pieces. It might be a little pricy to some people, but each candy is individually wrapped by hands :)
author: erik b.

description: This place is great! If you love the taste of peanut butter you would love this dragon beard dessert. It not super sweet bit it has an interesting texture; the candy itself is a stringy material and when you start chewing it turns into a tacky, sticky texture. I really enjoyed it, but I wouldn't give it 5 stars because for the amount you get and the price its just too expensive. 8 pieces for $10 thats too expensive for me, the pieces are small (size of a ketchup bag), the pictures here on yelp don't depict the true size of the dragon beard candy.
author: Leilani M.

description: Every one should try at least once. Such a unique candy experience. We (4 adults) laughed a lot as the little beard strings flew everywhere upon biting the candy.
author: Melissa O.

description: Got this as a gift recently. Adults and kids all loved it! We called it Hogwart candy since it magically disappears in your mouth with a cloud of smoke. Really! You have to try it to see what I mean! It's not too sweet and unlike any dessert I've ever had. Having seen the amount of labor involved, I think it is well worth the $9 a box to support this small kind of business. And next time I'm in SF, I'd definitely go get a box or two or three! They do make great gifts.. and with holidays right around the corner.. I can think of all the teachers at my kids school who may want a box.. I hope this lost art won't be lost to SF Chinatown in the future!
author: Christine W.

description: Definitely worth it. Obsessed with it. Though you need to wait sometimes, it's worth it! I don't even like coconut, but I liked this :) if yours is extremely chewy, it's probably been set out for awhile, but for the most part their products are fresh.
author: Jewelle B.

description:
This was an unexpected Chinatown find on my trip to SF. I've tried other dragon beard candies from fairs and regular markets, but they were obviously not as fresh. You can always distinguish the quality of this particular type of candy by the density of the spun sugar shell. The one at Dragon Papa was light and wispy, not to mention the man spinning the sugar out front must mean it's fresh. The peanuts inside weren't stale either! Yes, I've had a few bad ones that were purchased in a market :P

It was definitely a treat, and a place worth stopping by. I ended up purchasing 5 for the road.
author: Cristin P.

description: Definitely one of a kind shop especially considering their famous "Dragon Beard"  candy. I just happened to stumbled across the store on my exploration of the city by foot. Next thing you know, I pulled out my phone and jumped on YELP and pulled them up. Overall reviews were good then again I need to see and taste it for myself before I come to my own conclusion. So, I went ahead and purchased one pack of "Dragon Beard" candy and brought it home. The texture and taste itself isn't something new to me because I've had something similar in the past (dimsum). Of course that is where the similarity ends. It's really fluffy, very delicate to the touch sort of like touching raw silk before it's been made into something else. Ultra flaky, crunchy and depending on the temperature when you try it it's something to try. Looking at the two and three star review... It's obvious they're too critical on the candy. Yes, it's not fancy and yes it does cost a bit considering that it's only desert but so is a lot of things in san Francisco. Have those people ever tried small boutique shop. Try throwing out $20 for a few piece of chocolate or $5 buck cupcake or dropping by "Off the Grid"  for over price small portion snack. It's not about the price, but the experience...Welcome to San Francisco. If you're too frugal... Window shop (last time I heard it's still free).
author: Seng S.

description: Really wanted to try this place after all the great reviews. The candy was very dry. Wouldn't recommend eating this without a beverage. And very overpriced. $9 for a tiny box. Doesn't seem worth it for something that doesn't taste that great.
author: S. S.

description: The dragon beard candy may be a little messy to eat but well worth it. For $9 each we got the original and coffee flavors. The original reminded me of a Filipino polvoron encased in this wonderful angel hair type wrapping.  The owner and staff are friendly and it was entertaining to see the candy being made in the window.  It's definitely a rare confection to find in any Chinatown and I plan to go back for more.
author: Arlene M.

description: Love all candys!!!!!! Highly recommend Mochi, soooooo yummy! Definitely will come again XD
author: Jiayi W.

description: This place is worth going to find. I was hesitant but when I found it father son combo walked me through the whole process and what it entails in making this delicious candy. It melts in your mouth and becomes sticky but the peanuts crunch gives it the Abazaba taste you are craving.
author: Jeannie R.

description: I was taking a cousin & her friend, who just moved out from Minnesota, through Chinatown & north beach.  We came across this place & were anxious to try it as this was a first for all of us.  It is a very small shop & the owner is friendly.  They had a three for deal; I do not know how much we payed but it was excellent.  I had the mango which was kind of like granulated sugar & peanuts with mango inside; it was sort of like cotton candy in how lite it was.  We will definitely return.  So, for some excellent dragon bierd candy at reasonable prices, Dragon Papa cannot be beat.  Keep up the good work guys.
author: Brian S.

description:
I mean - would I ever go to this place again?  110 % not a chance.  $9.00 for 8 pieces of really really really tough taffy with peanuts inside.  As far as novelty goes, it is cool, but loses it after your first bite into this candy.

Flavor wise, it is pretty good, though nothing special in the way of chinese filled peanut pastries and candy goes.  The texture is awful and really cavity inducing.  It looks like it would be some soft chewy noodle thing. But man, This stuff sticks to your teeth worse than taffy does.  I don't know, would these people who give this place 4 or 5 stars come here regularly, or spend $9.00 to give this as a gift to someone?

Like Golden Gate Bakery, the masses just don't know any better.
author: Derek C.

description:
